application_procedure: Applicants should submit a cover letter, C.V. (including previous teaching evaluations (if applicable)), and a list of references by August 26, 2022. Applications should be sent to manager@utias.utoronto.ca.
duties:
• Developing syllabus and preparing lectures.
• Teaching twice weekly: Mondays & Tuesdays, 15:00-17:00. 
• Conducting scheduled office hours for academic counselling of students. 
• Evaluation of tests and the final examination.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than past teaching experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
An academic background in Mechanical Engineering or Aerospace Engineering, with a focus on thermodynamics, combustion, or energy systems. Prior teaching assistantship experience in thermodynamics, fluid mechanics, heat transfer, or combustion courses an asset. 
Knowledge in Thermodynamics & Chemical Kinetics (enthalpy, entropy, heats of formation and reaction, adiabatic flame temperature), Combustion Theory & Flame Physics (premixed and diffusion flames), Pollutant Formation and Control (NOx, SOx, CO, particulate matter formation), Application of Combustion in Devices (internal combustion engines, gas turbines, rocket propulsion, industrial furnaces), Modeling and Simulation (CFD tools).
qualifications_preferred: A graduate degree and industry or research experience in combustion-related fields preferred.
salery: $9,276.01 (plus vacation pay); or $10,366.55 (plus vacation pay) if first CI appointment

job_title: CTL7002H 0151 - Curriculum and Teaching in Mathematics
application_procedure: All applications must be received by the deadline date. Please indicate in a letter of application why you believe your experience qualifies you to teach this particular course. Please include a current CV and letters from three referees. Applications should be sent to: E-mail: ctlsessionals@utoronto.ca. If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact ctlsessionals@utoronto.ca.
duties: This course is offered as a required course in the MT program. The instructor is expected to prepare, organize, and teach this course, be available to students seeking assistance between classes. Evaluate and provide students with timely feedback on their work.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: 1 - Candidates must be Doctoral students in a relevant discipline with demonstrated currency and mastery of the subject area; 2 - Mastery may be demonstrated, but not limited to scholarly publications establishing expertise in the area.; 3 - Experience demonstrated excellence in teaching graduate courses.  Demonstrated knowledge and practice of equity, diversity and inclusion required.
qualifications_preferred: Relevant teacher experiences in K-12 settings in a relevant discipline.
salery: Minimum stipend is $9,276.01 (per half course excludes vacation pay).

department: Daniels Faculty of Architecture, Landscape, and Design
application_procedure: For detailed information, please refer to faculty website:  https://www.daniels.utoronto.ca/employment-opportunities
duties: In this course, TA will be responsible for supervising the robotic fabrication and construction of a small pavilion over an intensive 2 week period. Students must have experience and teachable competence using Rhinoceros Kuka PRC, safe operation of a Kuka Robotic industrial arm, 3 axis CNC, power tools, and hand tools safely and accurately. They will actively participate in the students’ understanding of material taught during class and provide assistance in both tutorials and during the fabrication and installation. In addition to attending class, tutorials and fabrication they will assist in grading assignments, this position also requires administrative duties related to fabrication coordination and on site assembly.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Advanced knowledge of Rhinoceros and Grasshopper, with specific knowledge and application of Kuka PRC in grasshopper, knowledge of DFMA (Design For Manufacturing and Assembly) processes in Grasshopper for geometry to robotic fabrication pipeline.
Experience with operations and programming of industrial Kuka robotic arm
Experience in robotic milling and safety operations of robotic arms.
Construction knowledge and experience in past executed 1:1 structural prototyping and demonstrators.
Woodshop knowledge and experience.
CNC knowledge and experience.
qualifications_preferred:
"GPA above 3.5 in studio. Previous work experience in the Daniels Workshop or in Construction.
Prior experience with Physical Computing and Artificial Intelligence is desired."

department: Centre for Industrial Relations & Human Resources
appointment_size: 120-150 TA hours, depending on course enrolment.
application_procedure: For detailed information on the application procedure go to https://www.cirhr.utoronto.ca/employment-opportunities/cirhr-job-postings.   Select the accordion named: "CUPE Unit 1 Opportunities - Undergraduate"  and follow the instructions listed there.
duties:
The position may include: marking tests and/or exams and assignments; holding tutorials; meeting with
students on an individual basis.  TAs are usually required to attend lecture unless they have previous experience with the course. Tutorials will be held, and TA will be expected to assist students with "R" system etc.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Individuals applying for the position should have an academic background which includes completion
of courses in industrial relations or organizational behaviour, and must be a registered student or Postdoctoral Fellow (PDF) at the University of Toronto on the starting date of the appointment and will remain eligible to work in the bargaining unit for the duration of the appointment.
qualifications_preferred: Someone who has completed an undergraduate or graduate level course in this or similar area. Familiarity with the "R" system is required, as TA must assist students with this in tutorials.

duties: All normal duties related to the design and teaching of a University credit course, including, but not restricted to, preparation and delivery of course content; out-of-class interactions with students via e-mail and regular office hours; development, administration and marking of assignments, tests and exams; calculation and submission of grades; and supervision of TAs/Graders (if any) as required. The instructor is expected to be fully available for the duration of the employment period. (NOTE: The mode of instruction for this course is expected to be online. However, if this changes for any reason, as much advance notice as practicable will be given.)
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Demonstrated ability in the specific area of the course (international relations/globalization processes) is required.
qualifications_preferred: Graduate-level research in leadership dimension or related area is preferred. Experience in this course or a similar course is preferred.

application_procedure:
Please submit your application on FASE TAMS using this link: 

https://tams.fase.utoronto.ca/TamsPortal/posting/543

The application (assembled in a SINGLE pdf and uploaded to TAMS) must include (i) a cover letter that outlines your relevant teaching experience, (ii) your resume, and (iii) a copy of your undergraduate grade report.  If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact Diane Giang at director.engsci@utoronto.ca.
duties: The Engineering Science Thesis TA provides administrative support to the Engineering Science Thesis Course (communicating with students and supervisors, posting grades, scheduling the thesis presentations, etc), assists in the planning and running of workshops to support students in completing their deliverables, and assesses thesis presentations. All fourth-year students in Engineering Science are required to complete a half or full-year thesis, and submit several deliverables, including a proposal, an interim report, a presentation and a final report.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: We are looking for candidates who have excellent oral and written communication skills, experience working with the administrative side of an undergraduate course (or good organizational skills from other experiences), and can identity opportunities for improvement and provide feedback to program staff.
qualifications_preferred: Preference may be given to graduates of Engineering Science at U of T.

duties: Arrangement of details for approximately 25 internships; Maintain a database of potential internship hosts; Liaise with internship hosts to help them plan for incoming students and to understand their responsibilities; Provide advice on incorporating new/innovative ideas for inclusion in an experiential learning course; Assist in developing assignments. Marking. Office hours.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Familiarity with the Human, Environmental and Physical Geography and GIS sub-fields; experience with experiential learning and familiar with associated pedagogical approaches; experience in social activism and interest planning. Prior experience. Preference will be given to graduate students enrolled in a Geography & Planning program. Course and timetabling information can be found at https://ttb.utoronto.ca/

application_procedure:
Only applications submitted to the email address listed below will be considered. Please include the closing date of the posting in your email subject line. Applicants should submit the following documents by July 23rd, 2025:  
•	A cover letter outlining suitability for the position (normally 1-2 pages)
•	An updated curriculum vitae
•	Sample instructional materials.  These instructional materials should be a maximum of 15 pages, attached to the application email. Please note that we cannot search through online documents. Please only send curriculum materials related to the teaching of writing (rather than entire dossiers and general teaching philosophy statements). Sample instructional materials may include but are not limited to handouts, activities, assignment instructions, presentation slides, multi-modal curricula, and course outlines.
•	A 3-10 page sample of academic writing
•	Names and contact information for three referees
•	Applications should be sent to the following: 

Dr. Marci Prescott-Brown, Director, New College Writing Centre
c/o Winston Tran, Program Administrator
newcollege.wcpositions@utoronto.ca
Applications must be submitted by email to the address listed above.  Do not submit your application via the University of Toronto website, as we cannot access them. 
Please include the posting closing date and position number in your email subject line.
duties:
The New College Writing Centre invites applications for one writing teaching assistant position in Unit 1 for the 2025/26 Fall/Winter Session. This position will start in September 2025 and will continue through the end of April 2026. This is a specialist position; in it, the successful applicant will lead the QT—Write Ins, a group open to the New College 2SLGBTQ+ community and allies and one of the New College Writing Centre’s (NCWC) inclusive spaces. This group provides writing welcome for students as they create their writing assignments and personal creative projects during the Fall and Winter terms. This position will be at least 100 hours; administrative duties as well as teaching will be important in this role. The successful applicant will also teach in the one-on-one program in the NCWC and may also create writing workshops. Applicants should be prepared to teach both in-person and online.  The person in this role will liaise with various student services in the New College context to deliver innovative programing. 

The context: 
New College is a large undergraduate college at the University of Toronto, with a strong focus on social justice and community engagement. Home to a culturally and linguistically diverse student body, New College also houses the highest percentage of international students of any U of T college. Our innovative, interdisciplinary academic programs—African Studies, Critical Solidarity and Equity Studies, and Buddhist Psychology and Mental Health—seek to promote social responsibility, diversity, critical equity and global awareness.   
The New College Writing Centre offers skilled, sensitive and welcoming writing instruction designed to enable students to realize their full potential as learners and contributors to knowledge production—in their fields of study, in the wider community, and in professional life. Our approach to writing instruction emphasizes writing as a complex ability that is continuously learned and relearned in relation to changing contexts and purposes. We value the linguistic diversity that students bring to their writing. 
This writing teaching assistant position will involve providing one-to-one writing instruction to undergraduate students working in a variety of disciplines, including academic programs housed at New College (http://www.newcollege.utoronto.ca/academics/new-collegeacademic-programs/); additional writing instruction in drop-in writing communities as well as writing workshops may also be included. The teaching assistant will provide instruction in critical analysis, critical reading, modes of argument, research skills, and methods for drafting and revising texts and for preparing oral presentations. 
The New College Writing Centre works with students enrolled in our academic programs in addition to students registered at New College who are taking Arts & Science courses more broadly. We encourage applicants who are reflective about the role of faculty in welcoming and mentoring a diverse range of students.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
•	At least a completed Masters degree
•	Familiarity with queer scholarship/theory 
•	Demonstrated community building and advocacy in the 2SLGBTQ+ community
•	An active registration in a program in the School of Graduate Studies at the University of Toronto
•	Demonstrated ability to teach writing and communication skills to students from diverse cultural and linguistic backgrounds
•	Previous experience teaching writing at the university level, either in a university writing centre and/or in university level courses with significant writing components
•	Excellent written and oral communication skills
•	Demonstrated ability to teach academic writing and critical skills in a one-to-one mode and across a variety of disciplines and programs, including those of New College
•	Demonstrated ability to facilitate interactive workshops
•	Familiarity with forms of writing and oral communication in a broad range of disciplinary curricula
•	Superior ability to work closely with the genre, rhetoric and grammar of student texts 
•	The ability to work cooperatively and effectively in a highly collaborative environment
qualifications_preferred: The following qualifications would be an asset in this position: lived experience as a member of the 2SLGBTQ+ community, prior experience facilitating writing opportunities in the 2SLGBTQ+ community, a completed PhD or completed PhD coursework.

duties: Assist course instructor with the delivery of undergraduate labs including but not limited to supervising students work in a lab environment, demonstrating the use of lab equipment and techniques, communicating clearly and effectively in terms of expectations, evaluating laboratory student performance, ensuring a safe and effective learning environment; keeping clear records of student grades and communicating these to students appropriately and consistent with UofT guidelines. Assist in the set-up of certain experiments and/or demonstrations and clean-up of assigned teaching area and common lab areas.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Candidates should be enrolled or should have made application to be enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies, University of Toronto with strong written and oral communication skills, strong laboratory skills, clear understanding of laboratory safety, experience working safely in an experimental chemistry laboratory and a demonstrated commitment to teaching. Candidates should have strong foundational knowledge of organic and inorganic chemistry, instrumental analysis (IR, GC), and organic chemistry techniques (TLC, melting point apparatus, distillation, liquid-liquid extraction). Candidate should hold a bachelor's degree in Chemical Engineering, Chemistry, or Engineering Chemistry. Preference will be given to those with a background in Chemical Engineering due to the alignment with the course objectives and content.
qualifications_preferred: Previous experience with microscale equipment and in a teaching lab environment would be an asset.
salery: $53.92 per hour + vacation pay. Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

qualifications_minimum: Candidates should be enrolled or should have made application to be enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies, University of Toronto with strong written and oral communication skills and a demonstrated commitment to teaching. Candidates should hold a bachelor's degree in Engineering, with a degree in Chemical Engineering being preferred. Preference will be given to those with a background in Chemical Engineering due to the alignment with the course objectives and content.
qualifications_preferred: Candidates should be enrolled within MASc or PhD program within the Department of Chemical Engineering and Applied Chemistry.
salery: $53.92 per hour + vacation pay. Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

application_procedure: Applicants should send the requested documents below to the attention of Prof. Arsalan Kahnemuyipour, Chair, Department of Language Studies, UTM via email to jobslanguagestudies.utm@utoronto.ca by the posted deadline: 1. DLS Unit 1 Job Application form (Please submit your information here: https://forms.office.com/r/94cuaqRR5T, then "print to PDF" to save a copy of the submission), 2. Cover letter (this should include a statement on the applicant's background and experience with respect to the posted qualifications), and 3. Current academic CV.
duties: Grading various types of online assessments, monitoring Quercus lectures and discussions. Other responsibilities are as assigned by the instructor and may include: course orientation, preparation, and meetings with the instructor. (Note: The mode of instruction for this course is ONLINE SYNCHRONOUS.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Demonstrated ability in the specific area of the course (neorealism, contemporary Italian cinema, cinema studies, etc.), is required. Native, or near-native, fluency in written and spoken Italian is required.
qualifications_preferred: Graduate-level research in Italian Studies is preferred. Experience in this course or a similar course is preferred.
salery: $52.97/hour + vacation pay.  Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

application_procedure: This job is posted in accordance with the CUPE 3902 Unit 1 Collective Agreement. Positions posted here are open to Graduate Students in the School of Graduate Studies and Postdoctoral Fellows. Preference in hiring shall be given to Graduate Students enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies of the University of Toronto or those who have made application to be enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies of the University of Toronto. Visit the Lawrence Bloomberg Faculty of Nursing website for instructions on how to apply for Teaching Assistant positions https://bloomberg.nursing.utoronto.ca/current-students/teaching-assistantships/. The University of Toronto is strongly committed to diversity within its community and especially welcomes applications from racialized persons / persons of colour, women, Indigenous / Aboriginal People of North America, persons with disabilities, LGBTQ2S+ persons, and others who may contribute to the further diversification of ideas. Candidates who are members of Indigenous, Black, racialized and LGBTQ2S+ communities, persons with disabilities, and other equity seeking groups are encouraged to apply, and their lived experience shall be taken into consideration as applicable to the position. The University strives to be an equitable and inclusive community, and proactively seeks to increase diversity among its community members. Our values regarding equity and diversity are linked with our unwavering commitment to excellence in the pursuit of our academic mission. The University is committed to the principles of the Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities Act (AODA). As such, we strive to make our recruitment, assessment and selection processes as accessible as possible and provide accommodations as required for applicants with disabilities. If you require any accommodation at any point during the application and hiring process, please contact uoft.careers@utoronto.ca. During employment, to request accommodation from the University, contact the supervisor or department chair and/or Health & Wellbeing Programs & Services at hwb@utoronto.ca. For more information about accommodations at UofT, please visit our Accommodation webpage. Duties of this position shall be performed at the campus on which the position is located. Where the duties are intended to be performed at another location, such other location will be specified in the posting.
duties: On-campus classes with in-person tests/exams if possible; Meetings with supervisor; Course orientation, marking meetings and as per supervisor request; Reading text and journal articles relevant to course content and assignments; Marking, grading and providing feedback for assignments and papers (complete all grading for all student work that is completed during the term of the appointment, up to and including final exams); Monitoring and responding to Quercus postings and email enquiries from students; Meeting and providing support with students during TA & requested hours; Invigilating exam; assist with tabulation of grades; Attending lecture and learning settings as negotiated with supervisor.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Masters or PhD students; Current UofT graduate students in good standing; CNO registration; interest in teaching and working with novice nursing students; Clinical expertise and experience relevant to the specific course and clinical focus; The hiring criteria for Teaching Assistant positions are academic qualifications, the need to acquire experience, previous experience and previous satisfactory employment under the provisions of this Collective Agreement.

duties: Grading Assistants will be required to assist in the preparation and dissemination of multi-media materials, and provide grading support that includes making detailed comments and marking of online assignments, tests, and exams.  They also will be responsible for answering student questions and queries through email, holding weekly virtual office hours, helping to manage the course’s online platforms, keeping track of marks, monitoring student discussion boards; occasional attendance of online lectures and other duties as determined by the supervisor.

application_procedure: Apply here: https://cupeha.utm.utoronto.ca/dept/ummgt/app/instr
duties: The duties of Course Instructors shall include the normal duties associated with the design and teaching of university degree credit courses or sections of courses. These include the preparation and delivery of course content, including lectures and/or seminars; creation of course ware; the development/administration of assignments, tests and examinations; the marking/grading of student work and the submission of grades to appropriate University officials in accordance with policy; the maintenance of reasonable hours of student contact outside of scheduled contact hours; and the supervision of the day-to-day work of any Sessional Instructional Assistants or Teaching Assistants assigned to the course.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Course Instructors are expected to be of superior teaching ability, with suitable academic and/or professional qualifications, currency and mastery of the subject matter. Successful applicants will have clearly demonstrated teaching excellence in the subject matter through previous experience teaching the course in question, or very similar courses.
qualifications_preferred: Successful applicants will typically have significant experience in applying the subject matter in a practical environment.

job_title: utmONE: Critical Thinking for STEM Learning
department: Institute for the Study of University Pedagogy
application_procedure: All applicants should  apply via https://cupeha.utm.utoronto.ca/. Please contact Malisa Zhou (malisa.zhou@utoronto.ca), Acting Academic Advisor, for any questions or concerns.
duties: Duties may include: Preparation of course tutorials; holding office hours; conducting twelve tutorials of two types: six regular (content-based) and six ONE tutorials (first-year transition support); attending and completing TA training (if applicable); marking assignments, tests, and exams; performing general administrative duties relating to the course; invigilating tests, exams, and field trips as required. Specific duties are defined by Instructor in charge of the course and outlined in the description of duties and allocation of hours form. Duties of this position shall be performed at the campus on which the position is located.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Enrolment as a Masters or Doctoral student.
qualifications_preferred: Appropriate background in the subject. Preference will be given to candidates with substantial experience in teaching / running tutorials at the post-secondary level.
tutorial: Please refer to https://ttb.utoronto.ca/ for the most up to date schedule information.

job_title: Psychological Assessment II: Neuropsychological and Intellectual Assessment
application_procedure: Apply using link https://www.utsc.utoronto.ca/webapps/cupehiring/
duties: Duties for the position may vary and include: grading short answers on exams, administrative and clerical duties, holding exam review sessions, occassional class attendance for hands on practice work, email contact with students. Specific duties will be outlined in the DDAH form.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Includes: ability, academic qualifications, suitability for the position and appropriate background in the subject/specialty, specifically strong background in graduate level Clinical psychology. Applicants must be familiar with intelligence tests and their scoring, as well as neuropsychological assessments, and standardized cognitive test measures.
qualifications_preferred: Graduate student within the Clinical Psychology Program who has successfully completed this course.

application_procedure: Apply using link https://www.utsc.utoronto.ca/webapps/cupehiring/
duties: Duties for the position may vary and include: Leading in-person practicals, exam and assignment grading, holding office hours, assisting with the development of exam material. Specific duties will be outlined in the DDAH.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Includes: ability, academic qualifications, previous experience, & previous satisfactory employment, appropriate background in the subject/specialty, specifically strong background and training in systems/cellular neuroscience. Experience with electrophysiological recording techniques (in vivo or in vitro) preferred but not required.  You must be available to lead a practical in order to accept this position.
qualifications_preferred: Graduate work in Neuroscience

application_procedure: Apply using link https://www.utsc.utoronto.ca/webapps/cupehiring/
duties: Duties for the position may vary and include: Conducting in-person weekly tutorials, supervising and grading research proposals/writing assignment, designing/grading weekly quizzes, marking exams, holding office hours and answering student emails, clerical and administrative duties, and student paper consultations. Specific duties will be outlined in the DDAH.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Includes: ability, academic qualifications, suitability for the position and appropriate background in the subject/specialty, specifically strong background (education or research) in neuroscience, learning and motivation theories. Must have excellent communication and writing skills. Applicant must be available to lead an in-person tutorial in order to accept the position.

application_procedure: Apply using link https://www.utsc.utoronto.ca/webapps/cupehiring/
duties: Duties may vary and include: leading in-person tutorials and lab demonstrations, generating data before labs for students to prep, supervising live rat experiments, preparing historical pictures of brains, performing stats workshops, monitoring student data analyses, leading breakout groups during lectures, grading papers and assignments. Specific duties will be outlined in the DDAH.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Includes: ability, academic qualifications, suitability for the position and appropriate background in the subject/specialty, specifically strong background and training in behavioural and systems neuroscience. Applicants should be expert in the use of operant boxes (lever pressing for food), mazes (water maze, elevated plus maze) and other related equipment (Open field). Some applicants may be invited for an interview with the professor to assess background knowledge.

job_title: Computers in Psychological Research: Advanced Topics
application_procedure: Apply using link https://www.utsc.utoronto.ca/webapps/cupehiring/
duties:
Duties will vary and include: creation of demonstration materials in tutorials, leading practicals, creating and 
overseeing remote testing, grading assignments, supervising student  analyses and projects
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Includes: ability, academic qualifications, suitability for the position and appropriate background in the subject/specialty, specifically strong background and training in computer-based implementations of 
experimental design, data processing and result interpretation in psychology, visual stimulus design, fixed and adaptive stimulus presentation, behavioral data recording, practical implementation and assessment of univariate / multivariate statistical tests, data exploration via basic computational models,  graphical representation of data structure and result interpretation. Applicants should be expert in MatLab,Statistics, Image processing, Bioinformatics, and Psychtoolbox. job_title: Math and Stats Support- Head TA
application_procedure: https://www.utsc.utoronto.ca/webapps/cupehiring/dept/ctl/app/ta
duties:
Duties may include: assisting the coordinator with organizing and facilitating TA training sessions; meeting periodically with the MSS Coordinator; holding in-person and virtual office hours for CTL’s Math and Statistics Support program; helping students with their calculus courses; delivering workshops and exam review seminars in-person and in an online setting; providing virtual one-to-one sessions; responding to student queries by email and Quercus Forum discussions; filming educational materials, if there is a student demand for it; and helping with MSS initiatives and promotion such as U(t)-Mathazine and Math in Action Journal. For Fall 2025 and Winter 2026, some duties will be completed on campus. Teaching assistants should also have access to a stable, high-speed internet line, a computer with a working webcam and microphone and a quiet workspace.

Appointment Dates: September 2, 2025 to April 30, 2026
Weekly Scheduled Hours: To be arranged.
To complete the application, please upload:
1. Cover Letter (indicate student status (eg. first year of M. Sc program) at the beginning of the term in the Cover Letter)
2. CV or Resume
3. Transcript (Unofficial is acceptable)
4. Names and contact information of THREE references.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: A successful applicant has a minimum Master's Degree in Math. Solid knowledge of Calculus courses in undergraduate programs at the University of Toronto, Scarborough campus is a requirement. Applicants should have excellent communication skills and a minimum of 3 years of teaching experience or TA experience in the field of Mathematics; demonstrated experience leading and facilitating TA meetings is required.
qualifications_preferred: A solid understanding of CTL's Math and Stats Support Program and previous MSS TA experience will be an asset . Experience conducting and holding review seminars and workshops would be an asset. An average grade of A- in four C or D level math courses and familiarity with web conferencing tools such as Microsoft Teams and Zoom would be an asset.
salery:
January 1, 2025 : Undergraduate (UG)/SGS I/SGS II/PDF: $52.97 per hour
January 1, 2026: Undergraduate (UG)/SGS I/SGS II/PDF: $53.92 per hour

duties: Grading of assessments and teaching of weekly tutorials. Preference will be given to those with a background in Chemical Engineering due to the alignment with the course objectives and content.

duties: Creation of new materials (e.g., lecture content, labs, assignments, tests). Creation/modification of testing environments (e.g., unit tests, pytests, MarkUs testing) and feedback systems to improve student learning/understanding. Creation/development of course site (e.g., website, Quercus, MCS Download Site, Piazza, etc.) and setup of pertinent systems (i.e., PCRS and MarkUs). Duties for this position run in early July to early October. Must be available to meet at least two times per week synchronously during business hours. Must be available to communicate updates and progress daily via Email, Slack, and Microsoft Teams. This is an emergency position.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Expertise with Python, pytests, doctests, and unit tests is required. Expertise with Git version control and LaTeX is required. Proficiency with setting up, maintaining, and running the infrastructure used for autotesting (MarkUs and its test cases) and detecting code similarity (e.g., MOSS, jPlag) is also required. Expertise with the CSC108 content, CSC148 content, and beyond. Strong grades in a minimum of 3.0 FCEs of CSC courses from UTM, including at least 1.0 FCEs of systems courses. Note that CSC-like courses offered in different departments do not count towards the FCE requirement as the courses offered in other departments or in other campuses differ widely in content, coverage, or expectations.
Must be familiar with this course offering from UTM and the UTM compute infrastructure. Strong organizational skills and strong written/spoken English communication skills, including a demonstrated and consistent ability to complete work on time and with a high level of attention to detail.

duties: Must be available in-person at least 2 days (ideally 3-4 days) per week during regular business/working hours for practicals/labs/tutorials/lectures/office hours. Teaching Assistants must be available evenings and weekends (online) when assigned to manage the discussion boards, especially close to assessment deadlines. Teaching Assistants will need to run and manage labs/practicals/tutorials, office hours, and even assist/support instructors in teaching lectures in-person at UTM. Should be comfortable generating CSC108 related content and questions for assessments (including tests and examinations) and for extra-help problems. Lab TAs and Lecture TAs are expected to adequately prepare before each lab or lecture session. All TAs will be responsible for grading which will occur on evenings, weekends, and during business hours. Prompt completion of grading with tight turnaround times (within the specifications of the Collective Agreement, and as discussed with the course coordinator), is essential to the operation of this course and is a requirement for this role.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Experience coding in the Python programming language (writing multi-function and multi-file programs; building unittests, doctests, and pytests). Note that CSC-like courses offered in different departments do not count towards the FCE requirement as the courses offered in other departments or in other campuses differ widely in content, coverage, or expectations. Able to effectively run and manage labs/practicals/tutorials/lectures, mark assessments (labs, assignments, tests, exams), hold office hours, respond to emails and discussion boards (including responding to technical questions) and effectively manage and answer questions on the course discussion board. Demonstrated record of commitment to teaching pedagogy and student learning. Demonstrated record of timeliness in communication and carrying out duties, and demonstrates promptness and reliability in all responsibilities. Excellent organizational skills and strong written & spoken English communication skills. A demonstrated and consistent ability to complete work on time and communicate in a timely manner. High level of attention to detail. Familiarity with the undergraduate UTM experience and with the UTM computing environment in MCS.

experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Excellence in CSC347/CSC427 or equivalent. Experience with system, network and software security, including systems hardening and intrusion detection. Experience with VMWare, C, assembly and Unix. Experience with UTM systems and labs experience an asset. Additionally, excellence in OWASP top 10 including the ability to identify, manually (i.e., without the use of tools) carry out, and patch the top 10 vulnerabilities in software. Familiarity with security tools such as, but not limited to, reverse engineering tools (i.e., GDB, immunity, Ghidra), metasploit, burpsuite, networking tools, firewall configurations, and others. Strong grades in a minimum of 3.0 FCEs of CSC courses, including at least 1.0 FCEs of systems courses. Note that CSC-like courses offered in different departments do not count towards the FCE requirement as the courses offered in other departments or in other campuses differ widely in content, coverage, or expectations. Able to effectively run and manage labs/practicals/tutorials/lectures, mark assessments (labs, assignments, tests, exams), hold office hours, respond to emails, and effectively manage and answer questions on the course discussion board. Demonstrated record of commitment to teaching pedagogy and student learning. Demonstrated record of timeliness in communication and carrying out duties. Excellent organizational skills and strong written & spoken English communication skills. A demonstrated and consistent ability to complete work on time and communicate in a timely manner. High level of attention to detail. Familiarity with the undergraduate UTM experience and with the UTM computing environment.
qualifications_preferred: N/A

duties: Most TAs need to be available in person at UTM at least one day per week either to lead labs, to support lecture sessions, hold office hours, or attend meetings with the instructor. Applicants must explicitly indicate their in-person availability, not remote availability in the application system. Duties will include a combination of leading labs, grading assignments and tests, holding office hours, or helping with discussion board monitoring during peak question volumes. experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Extensive experience in C; knowledge of parallel programming paradigms (shared memory, message passing) and frameworks like pthreads, OpenMP, and MPI; solid understanding of concurrency, synchronization, scalability, and familiarity with GPU programming; strong familiarity with Unix/Linux tools; solid experience with version control, debuggers, compilers, and profiling tools (e.g., perf, gprof, valgrind, etc.); solid experience with performance measurements, application profiling, and performance analysis. Must have strong knowledge in Parallel Programming and Distributed Computing. Being familiar with the CSC367 offering from UTM and the UTM computing environment is a requirement. Having taken CSC469 (Advanced Operating Systems) and/or CSC409 (Scalable Computing) is a big plus. Strong grades in a minimum of 3.0 FCEs of CSC courses, including at least 1.0 FCEs of systems courses. Note that CSC-like courses offered in different departments do not count towards the FCE requirement as the courses offered in other departments or in other campuses differ widely in content, coverage, or expectations. Able to effectively run and manage labs/practicals/tutorials/lectures, mark assessments (labs, assignments, tests, exams), hold office hours, respond to emails, and effectively manage and answer questions on the course discussion board. Demonstrated record of commitment to teaching pedagogy and student learning. Demonstrated record of timeliness in communication and carrying out duties. Excellent organizational skills and strong written & spoken English communication skills. A demonstrated and consistent ability to complete work on time and communicate in a timely manner. High level of attention to detail. Familiarity with the undergraduate UTM experience and with the UTM computing environment.

qualifications_preferred: Graduate-level research in the specific subject area of this course is preferred. Experience in this course or a similar course is preferred.

application_procedure: https://utapmat.utm.utoronto.ca/utap/
duties: Will include some of the following: running tutorials, marking, invigilation, office hours, preparatory work, and other duties of administering the course.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Strong grades in a minimum of 3.0 FCEs of mathematics courses, including at least 1.0 FCEs of primarily proof-based courses. Note that "MAT-like" courses offered in different departments do not count towards the FCE requirement as they do not adhere to the standards of rigour used in mathematics courses. In the alternative, applicants whose portfolio includes at least 2.0 FCEs of MAT specialist classes will be deemed to have satisfied the FCE requirement. The candidate must have strong grades and demonstrated knowledge of the course content and beyond; have a demonstrated record of commitment to teaching pedagogy and student learning; have a demonstrated record of timeliness in communication and carrying out duties; and possess excellent communication skills and professionalism.
qualifications_preferred: Teaching experience preferred

application_procedure: https://www.utsc.utoronto.ca/webapps/cupehiring/dept/ctl/app/ta
duties:
Duties may include: holding in-person and virtual office hours for CTL’s Math and Statistics Support program; helping students with their calculus courses; delivering workshops and exam review seminars in-person and in an online setting; providing virtual one-to-one sessions; responding to student queries by email and Quercus Forum discussions; filming educational materials, if there is a student demand for it; and helping with MSS initiatives and promotion such as U(t)-Mathazine and Math in Action Journal. For Fall 2025 and Winter 2026, some duties will be completed on campus. Teaching assistants should also have access to a stable, high-speed internet line, a computer with a working webcam and microphone and a quiet workspace.

Appointment Dates: September 2, 2025 to December 23, 2025 or September 2, 2025 to April 30, 2026
Weekly Scheduled Hours: To be arranged.
To complete the application, please upload:
1. Cover Letter (indicate student status (eg. first year of M. Sc program) at the beginning of the term in the Cover Letter)
2. CV or Resume
3. Transcript (Unofficial is acceptable)
4. Names and contact information of THREE references.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: A successful applicant has solid knowledge of Calculus courses in undergraduate programs at the University of Toronto, Scarborough campus. Applicants with excellent communication skills and a minimum 1-2 years of teaching experience or TA experience in the field of Mathematics.
qualifications_preferred: An average grade of A- in four C or D level math courses and familiarity with web conferencing tools such as Microsoft Teams and Zoom would be an asset.
salery:
January 1, 2025 : Undergraduate (UG)/SGS I/SGS II/PDF: $52.97 per hour
January 1, 2026: Undergraduate (UG)/SGS I/SGS II/PDF: $53.92 per hour

duties:

Duties may be delivered remotely/online or in person. For Fall 2025 and Winter 2026, some duties will be completed on campus. Teaching assistants should also have access to a stable, high-speed internet line, a computer with a working webcam and microphone and a quiet workspace.

duties: TA duties include maintaining and updating the Quercus site (post rubrics, manage submission folders, and record grades), tracking student milestones and send reminder emails about upcoming deadlines, coordinating the schedule for mid‑year progress meetings and final presentations, coordinating presentations and final paper submission reviewing, providing concise written feedback on select written milestones (maximum 3 per student) using provided rubrics. job_title: Mathematics Concepts for Elementary Teacher Candidates
application_procedure: Please apply via https://hiring.oise.utoronto.ca/
duties:
CTL7100 MathPlus is a mandatory non-credit math course for Master of Teaching candidates enrolled in the Primary/Junior or Junior/Intermediate division. This course is not about math pedagogy or theory, but rather its purpose is to deepen the math content knowledge of teacher candidates (e.g., improving their skills in multi-digit multiplication, division, order of operations, fractions, decimals, percentages, ratios, integers, exponents, manipulating expressions and solving algebraic equations) and improve their math confidence.

Duties include: 24 hours of face to face teaching time, 12 two-hour classes throughout the fall-winter academic year, tracking homework completion, marking performance assessments, offering math content support to TCs when required, and attending three MathPlus meetings throughout the year. This course is delivered in-person during daytime hours.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Applicants must possess a strong knowledge of Grades 6 to 8 mathematics. Currency and mastery of the subject area are important. Candidates will be considered for multiple sections and we ask that you indicate if you are available to TA multiple sections in your cover letter.
qualifications_preferred: Preference will be given to candidates who have had successful experience with teaching mathematics to adult learners and learners with low math confidence.
salery: Fall 2025: $52.97 hourly plus applicable vacation pay; Winter 2026: $53.92 hourly plus applicable

application_procedure: Please apply via https://hiring.oise.utoronto.ca/
duties: The primary duty for this position is virtual office hour support for students.  TA's will set up online booking links and share them with the Research 1 Instructor team. TAs will familiarize themselves closely with the Research 1 course syllabus and assignment guidelines. They will meet with the TA supervisor at the start of the position and as requested over the course of the year. TAs will provide students with guidance in developing literature reviews (searching, citing, synthesizing, making meaning of the lit, researcher positionality). TAs will also facilitate two sessions of the annual MT Research Conference.  The TAs are expected to familiarize themselves closely with the literature review assignment expectations and evaluation instruments so that they can provide accurate and supportive guidance. Duties may also include preparing and/or reviewing resources to support students in their literature reviews.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Candidates should possess experience writing literature reviews and have experience conducting qualitative research. They should have a demonstrated commitment to researcher reflexivity, positionality, and critical citation practice. Candidates are expected to have experience teaching and/or supporting academic writing and experience with research design and qualitative research methods. Candidates should possess strong organizational and communication skills (oral and written), and have experience providing substantive and specific feedback on student work. Experience with academic coaching and writing support would be considered a strong asset.  Demonstrated knowledge and practice of equity, diversity and inclusion required. An Ontario Teaching Certificate is an asset.
qualifications_preferred: Candidates should possess experience writing literature reviews and have experience conducting qualitative research. They should have a demonstrated commitment to researcher reflexivity and critical citation practice. Candidates are expected to have experience teaching and/or supporting academic writing and experience with research design and qualitative research methods. Candidates should possess strong organizational and communication skills (oral and written), and have experience providing substantive and specific feedback on student work. Experience with academic coaching would be considered a strong asset.  Demonstrated knowledge and practice of equity, diversity and inclusion required. An Ontario Teaching Certificate is an asset.

application_procedure: Please apply via https://hiring.oise.utoronto.ca/
duties: Working as a member of a team of graduate students to: Offer one-to-one advising appointments to all OISE graduate students including teacher education students who require assistance with their oral and written communication skills in the following areas; academic writing (planning, organizing, writing and revising academic papers such as essays, MRPs, theses, dissertations, manuscripts for publication, funding applications, lesson plans, portfolios, personal journal entries); presentation skills (in-class presentations, conference presentations, lesson delivery); Provide support to teacher candidates in developing teacher skills (lesson planning process, mock lesson feedback) and developing strategies to meet the diverse needs of learners; In conjunction with the annual Professional Preparation Conference, provide support for teacher education students preparing for job applications and interviews; Provide individualized support for international students and new Canadians with their English language development (grammar, oral communication, listening, reading and pronunciation skills; Support international students and new Canadians in acculturating to the university environment; Support internationally educated teacher candidates to become familiar with the culture of Canadian K-12 schools; Promote the services of the OISE Student Success Centre to faculty members and students; Use the online appointment booking and tracking software to post summaries of appointments; Attend and contribute to regular team meetings.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: This position requires a high level of proficiency in English, strong communication and writing skills, strong interpersonal skills, as well as experience working with English language learners. Teaching experience is not mandatory but will be considered a significant asset in supporting some components of the OSSC's mandate and OISE students. You must be able to work well independently and as part of a team, create a learning climate of mutual respect and fairness, understand, develop, and provide a learning environment that supports diversity and inclusion. Many OSSC activities take place online and all advisors must be able to perform online appointments using the OSSC's online system. Therefore, it is expected that advisors have technological equipment with internet capabilities.
qualifications_preferred: Priority will be given to OISE doctoral students. Previous experience working in a university writing centre or teaching academic writing/skills courses.
salery: Fall 2025: $52.97 hourly plus applicable vacation pay; Winter 2026: $53.92 hourly plus applicable

This course will be delivered online.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: The TA must be fluent in both American Sign Language (ASL) and English. For ASL, the minimum level of proficiency required is Level 4 of ASLPI, with a preference for Level 5. Additionally, familiarity with various ASL curricula, such as TRUE+WAY ASL (TWA) and Signing Naturally, is essential.

Toronto, ON M5G 1Z5

duties:
Duties are in person unless otherwise indicated and will include any or all of the following:

Preparation for classes, preparation of written or audio-visual materials, designing and maintaining course websites, attending lectures, running tutorial sessions, facilitating and evaluating student engagement on online discussion boards, leading training sessions, meeting with the instructors, teaching, leading discussions, rating students' work, holding office hours, consulting with students (including electronic consultation), writing and grading tests, examinations and lab sets, grading essays and term papers, invigilating midterm and final exams, and conferring with the supervisor in charge, as required by the employee's teaching duties.
Duties of this position shall be performed on the St. George Campus.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Required:

o	Strong communication skills and ability to communicate statistical concepts to beginner statistics students
o	Experience in interpreting statistical results in plain English 
o	Experienced in using R, R-studio to produce plots, data summaries, and perform basic statistical tests
o	Experience developing tutorial materials, evaluation rubrics, and materials to support the development of student writing and speaking skills is an asset.
o	Must be available for teaching team meetings 5-6 times each term (two 2-hour sessions each day). The first two meetings will be in the first two weeks of the semester, and the others will be scheduled with the course instructor at a later date
o	Must be available during scheduled tutorial times on Fridays
qualifications_preferred:
Required:

o	Strong communication skills and ability to communicate statistical concepts to beginner statistics students
o	Experience in interpreting statistical results in plain English 
o	Experienced in using R, R-studio to produce plots, data summaries, and perform basic statistical tests
o	Experience developing tutorial materials, evaluation rubrics, and materials to support the development of student writing and speaking skills is an asset.
o	Must be available for teaching team meetings 5-6 times each term (two 2-hour sessions each day). The first two meetings will be in the first two weeks of the semester, and the others will be scheduled with the course instructor at a later date
o	Must be available during scheduled tutorial times on Fridays
salery:
Fall 2025: $52.97/hour (+4% vacation pay)
Winter 2026: $53.92/hour (+4% vacation pay)

o	Strong communication skills and ability to communicate statistical concepts to beginner statistics students
o	Experience in interpreting statistical results in plain English
o	Experienced in using R, R-studio to produce plots, data summaries, and perform basic statistical tests
o	Available for TA meetings 5-6 times each term (two 2-hour sessions each meeting day, tentatively scheduled for Wednesdays). The first two meetings will be in the first two weeks of the semester, and the others will be scheduled with the course instructor at a later date.
o	Available during scheduled tutorial times on Fridays
qualifications_preferred:
Preferred: 
o	Experience developing tutorial materials, evaluation rubrics, and materials to support the development of student writing and speaking skills is or a demonstrated interest to develop such skills
tutorial:
Meeting Schedule: 	Lecture:	MO:09:00-11:00 (tentative)
			Tutorials:	FR:09:00-11:00 (tentative)

application_procedure: All applications for this round to be submitted online at https://taships.iit.artsci.utoronto.ca/lin.  Please do not submit applications by email.  Contact linguistics@utoronto.ca if you have any questions.
duties: The Course Instructor position involves the normal duties related to the design, teaching, and timely administration of a university credit course, including but not restricted to (i) preparation and delivery of course content, (ii) development, administration and marking of assignments, tests and exams, (iii) calculation and submission of grades, (iv) holding regular office hours, (iv) supervision of TAs or Graders as required. Please consult the Arts & Science timetable to confirm the times and modality of the course.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: he successful candidate will hold ASLTA or ASL Instructor certification (or equivalent) and have knowledge of Deaf culture and/or lived experience with a Deaf community. Documentation of native or near-native fluency in ASL is required; scores should be submitted from an ASL Language Proficiency Interview (ASLPI) or other assessment conducted by a qualified organization (e.g. the Canadian Cultural Society of the Deaf, Gallaudet University, or the ASLTA). Evidence of prior successful teaching of ASL must be submitted along with the application (teaching evaluations, sample syllabi, etc.).
qualifications_preferred: A Master's or PhD in a relevant field is preferred. Previous experience working with Teaching Assistants/Graders is desirable. Excellent teaching evaluations and relevant active research are an asset. At least two semesters of experience working in the Department of Linguistics at UofT is an asset.

duties:
Duties are in person unless otherwise indicated and will include any or all of the following:

Preparation for classes, preparation of written or audio-visual materials, designing and maintaining course websites, attending lectures, running tutorial sessions, facilitating and evaluating student engagement on online discussion boards, participating in training sessions, meeting with the instructors, teaching, leading discussions, and supervising laboratories, rating students' work, holding office hours, consulting with students (including electronic consultation), writing and grading tests, examinations and lab sets, grading essays and term papers, invigilating midterm and final exams, setting up experiments, conducting field trips, and conferring with the supervisor in charge, as required by the employee's teaching duties.
Duties of this position shall be performed on the St. George Campus.

experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Applicants must have an academic background in human geography, physical geography, environmental science or environmental management.  Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_preferred: Applicants must have an academic background in human geography, physical geography, environmental science or environmental management.  Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.

department: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering
application_procedure: Please submit your teaching resume with cover letter as one (1) PDF to for each position you are interested in to ugta.ece@utoronto.ca.  Please label the PDF document using the following format: LastName, FirstName - CI - Course Code.  Messages in the body of the email will not be considered.  Please ONLY include your student number if you are a student. Otherwise UTORID/personnel if you are a Post-Doc. Deadline is July 18, 2025 at 11:59PM.
duties: Deliver lectures in accordance with class schedule and description; supervise TAs (if applicable); evaluate student's work and assign final grades.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Graduate students and post-doctoral fellows who possess and demonstrate expertise in the subject matter and have experience teaching (or serving as a teaching assistant in) in this or a similar course. The successful candidate must demonstrate a track record of professionalism and aptitude for instruction.
qualifications_preferred: Preference given to candidates with strong academic qualifications.  Ph.D. or post-doctoral fellows are preferred. Having repeated relevant experiences teaching (or having served as a teaching assistant) especially in this course offering is a strong asset.
salery:
$9,442.98 (excludes vacation pay) per half course.

Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

duties:
Duties are in person unless otherwise indicated and will include any or all of the following:

Preparation for classes, preparation of written or audio-visual materials, designing and maintaining course websites, attending lectures, running tutorial sessions, facilitating and evaluating student engagement on online discussion boards, participating in training sessions, meeting with the instructors, teaching, leading discussions, and supervising laboratories, rating students' work, holding office hours, consulting with students (including electronic consultation), writing and grading tests, examinations and lab sets, grading essays and term papers, invigilating midterm and final exams, setting up experiments, conducting field trips, and conferring with the supervisor in charge, as required by the employee's teaching duties.
Duties of this position shall be performed on the St. George Campus.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
o	Experienced in R, R-studio, tidyverse in producing simulations and interpreting results
o	Applicants must be available to lead weekly tutorials
o	Must demonstrate to have successfully completed this course or equivalent course in introductory probability
o	Good facilitation and presentation skills
o	Good oral and interpersonal skills, particularly able to show tact when communicating with students
qualifications_preferred:
o	Experienced in R, R-studio, tidyverse in producing simulations and interpreting results
o	Applicants must be available to lead weekly tutorials
o	Must demonstrate to have successfully completed this course or equivalent course in introductory probability
o	Good facilitation and presentation skills
o	Good oral and interpersonal skills, particularly able to show tact when communicating with students

duties:
Duties are in person unless otherwise indicated and will include any or all of the following:

Preparation for classes, preparation of written or audio-visual materials, designing and maintaining course websites, attending lectures, running tutorial sessions, facilitating and evaluating student engagement on online discussion boards, participating in training sessions, meeting with the instructors, teaching, leading discussions, and supervising laboratories, rating students' work, holding office hours, consulting with students (including electronic consultation), writing and grading tests, examinations and lab sets, grading essays and term papers, invigilating midterm and final exams, setting up experiments, conducting field trips, and conferring with the supervisor in charge, as required by the employee's teaching duties.
Duties of this position shall be performed on the St. George Campus.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
o	Applicants must be available to lead weekly tutorials
o	Must demonstrate to have successfully completed an upper year course in probability with an emphasis in probability theory
o	Good facilitation and presentation skills
o	Good oral and interpersonal skills, particularly able to show tact when communicating with students
qualifications_preferred:
o	Applicants must be available to lead weekly tutorials
o	Must demonstrate to have successfully completed an upper year course in probability with an emphasis in probability theory
o	Good facilitation and presentation skills
o	Good oral and interpersonal skills, particularly able to show tact when communicating with students

duties:
Duties are in person unless otherwise indicated and will include any or all of the following:

Preparation for classes, preparation of written or audio-visual materials, designing and maintaining course websites, attending lectures, running tutorial sessions, facilitating and evaluating student engagement on online discussion boards, participating in training sessions, meeting with the instructors, teaching, leading discussions, and supervising laboratories, rating students' work, holding office hours, consulting with students (including electronic consultation), writing and grading tests, examinations and lab sets, grading essays and term papers, invigilating midterm and final exams, setting up experiments, conducting field trips, and conferring with the supervisor in charge, as required by the employee's teaching duties.

experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Required:
o	Must demonstrate to have successfully completed a senior undergraduate course in regression analysis covering course topics or equivalent
o	Experience in conducting linear regression analysis, including assessment and correction of assumptions and appropriate model diagnostics
o	Experience performing statistical analyses and data manipulation in R and R-Studio
o	Strong organizational skills and ability to maintain tactful communication with students
qualifications_preferred:
Preferred: 
o	Experience in report writing and statistical communication
o	Experience providing written and formative feedback to others or a demonstrated interest to develop such skills
o	Familiarity with scientific report structure and best practices
o	Experience answering a variety of student questions (e.g., debugging code, writing advice, writing proofs and problem solving, data analysis techniques)

application_procedure:

Angela Niazmand
Undergraduate and TA Administrator
Department of Statistical Sciences

700 University Avenue
Ontario Power Building - 9160-6
Toronto, ON M5G 1Z5
www.statistics.utoronto.ca
E-mail: jobapps.statistics@utoronto.ca
duties:
Duties are in person unless otherwise indicated and will include any or all of the following:

Preparation for classes, preparation of written or audio-visual materials, designing and maintaining course websites, attending lectures, running tutorial sessions, facilitating and evaluating student engagement on online discussion boards, participating in training sessions, meeting with the instructors, teaching, leading discussions, and supervising laboratories, rating students' work, holding office hours, consulting with students (including electronic consultation), writing and grading tests, examinations and lab sets, grading essays and term papers, invigilating midterm and final exams, setting up experiments, conducting field trips, and conferring with the supervisor in charge, as required by the employee's teaching duties.
Duties of this position shall be performed on the St. George Campus.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Required: 
o	Strong programming skills in R with experience using advanced visualization libraries (e.g., ggplot2, Shiny, Plotly) 
o	Strong skills and experience with data visualization  
o	Familiarity with course topics such as perception, graphic design, visualization principles, and data-driven communication 
o	Previous teaching experience in interactive, problem-solving tutorials and labs 
o	Confident in assessing written reports, verbal presentations, and group projects 
o	Available to participate in training sessions throughout the term with the course instructor
qualifications_preferred:
Preferred: 
o	Experience with a range of visualization software/libraries such as Tableau, VegaLite, D3.js, etc... 
o	Previous teaching experience in related course(s) (e.g., STA313, JSC270/JSC370, STA2555, CSC2537, CSC318), and/or professional experience in the relevant subject matter.  
o	Successful completion in advanced related course(s) (e.g., STA313, STA2555, CSC2537, HAD5014, INF451) 
o	Familiarity with research methods in Human-Computer Interaction (HCI)
tutorial:
Meeting Schedule: 	Lecture:	WE:09:00-11:00; FR:13:00-14:00 (tentative)
			Tutorials:	N/A

duties:
Duties are in person unless otherwise indicated and will include any or all of the following:

Preparation for classes, preparation of written or audio-visual materials, designing and maintaining course websites, attending lectures, running tutorial sessions, facilitating and evaluating student engagement on online discussion boards, participating in training sessions, meeting with the instructors, teaching, leading discussions, and supervising laboratories, rating students' work, holding office hours, consulting with students (including electronic consultation), writing and grading tests, examinations and lab sets, grading essays and term papers, invigilating midterm and final exams, setting up experiments, conducting field trips, and conferring with the supervisor in charge, as required by the employee's teaching duties.
Duties of this position shall be performed on the St. George Campus.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Required:
o	Academic background in Statistical Sciences. PhD student (or graduate) in actuarial science, statistics or biostatistics.
o	Proficient in programming in R
o	Proficiency/knowledge in most, if not all, of the course topics indicated below is preferred:
•	Programming in an interactive statistical environment.
•	Generating random variates and evaluating statistical methods by simulation.
•	Algorithms for linear models, maximum likelihood estimation, and Bayesian inference.
•	Statistical algorithms such as the Kalman filter and the EM algorithm.
•	Graphical display of data.
qualifications_preferred:
Required:
o	Academic background in Statistical Sciences. PhD student (or graduate) in actuarial science, statistics or biostatistics.
o	Proficient in programming in R
o	Proficiency/knowledge in most, if not all, of the course topics indicated below is preferred:
•	Programming in an interactive statistical environment.
•	Generating random variates and evaluating statistical methods by simulation.
•	Algorithms for linear models, maximum likelihood estimation, and Bayesian inference.
•	Statistical algorithms such as the Kalman filter and the EM algorithm.
•	Graphical display of data.

duties:
Duties are in person unless otherwise indicated and will include any or all of the following:
Preparation for classes, preparation of written or audio-visual materials, designing and maintaining course websites, attending lectures, running tutorial sessions, facilitating and evaluating student engagement on online discussion boards, participating in training sessions, meeting with the instructors, teaching, leading discussions, and supervising laboratories, rating students' work, holding office hours, consulting with students (including electronic consultation), writing and grading tests, examinations and lab sets, grading essays and term papers, invigilating midterm and final exams, setting up experiments, conducting field trips, and conferring with the supervisor in charge, as required by the employee's teaching duties.
Duties of this position shall be performed on the St. George Campus.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Required:
o	Undergraduate degree with Statistics Minor or Major and current graduate student in Statistics, Biostatistics, or related discipline
o	Experience with quantitative life science research and/or analysis and interpretation of resulting data (e.g., coursework and/or research)
o	Experience performing statistical analyses using R/R Markdown and ability to troubleshoot technical issues
o	Available to attend class meetings in-person for both LEC sections to support students on weeks with scheduled class activities such as labs
qualifications_preferred:
Preferred: 
o	PhD candidate in Statistics, Biostatistics, or related discipline
o	Experience answering a variety of student questions (e.g., debugging code, writing advise, data analyses) or a demonstrated interest to develop such skill
o	Experience providing written and formative feedback to students or a demonstrated interest to develop such skill
o	Ability to communicate, both verbally and in writing, with a diverse team in a clear and precise manner
o	Ability to assist students search for and understand relevant literature
o	Familiarity with scientific report structure, scientific writing, and best practices
o	Previous TA experience and professional development in teaching (e.g., TATP workshops)
o	Previous experience with STA288H1: Statistics and Scientific Inquiry in the Life Sciences
