job_title: Coping with Complexity in Persistent Illness (Adult)
application_procedure: "Please click on the "How to Apply" tab on our website: https://bloomberg.nursing.utoronto.ca/careers/clinical-instructor-positions
duties:
The Lawrence Bloomberg Faculty of Nursing Program provides a full-time, two-year, second entry baccalaureate nursing education. Given that nursing is a practice-based profession, we believe that clinical experience is a vital and integral component of the curriculum, providing students with hands-on opportunities to actively apply classroom learning to ‘real life’ nursing practice under the supervision and support of a clinical teacher. Clinical Instructors (CIs) play an important role in facilitating student learning and providing excellent clinical learning experiences to further develop students’ knowledge, skill, and judgement. 
	
CIs should be flexible and prepared to utilize additional learning modalities such as simulation and virtual clinical learning in the event a clinical day is cancelled by the organization. CIs will work closely with the Clinical Education Office and Course Faculty to develop and share resources to support the continuity of clinical teaching and student learning. CIs are required to complete all on-boarding and orientation activities required by the faculty as well as the clinical placement site prior to the start of the placement in preparation for their clinical teaching role. Ongoing support will be provided throughout the term by Course Faculty, the Undergraduate Clinical Resource Faculty, and the Clinical Education Office.  Applicants should note that commitment to the role for the entire term is needed for consistency in the development, assessment, and evaluation of nursing students.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         Duties and Responsibilities:                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            1.	Complete the asynchronous CI orientation learning modules as required and attend the in-person Faculty-led CI orientation for NUR460.
2.	Complete all on-boarding and orientation required by the University as well as the clinical placement site prior to the first clinical shift.
3.	Familiarize themselves with and uphold all faculty and University policies related to clinical placements (e.g., CI and Student Absences, Professional Behaviour). 
4.	Attend all clinical shifts as scheduled. 
4A.	Personal obligations (e.g. attending conferences, vacations, or appointments) are to be scheduled outside of the clinical shifts. 
4B.	In the case of extenuating circumstances (e.g. illness and/or bereavement) - CIs are required to notify the Clinical Education Office with the dates as soon as possible. CIs may also be asked to assist the Clinical Education Office to arrange a possible replacement instructor. 
5.	Prepare patient assignments prior to students' arrival on the nursing unit, reflective of the students' level of expertise.
6.	Assist with and assess the students' preparation for their clinical activities with attention to integration of nursing, pathophysiological, pharmacologic, and therapeutic concepts.
7.	Encourage an inquiring, theory, and evidence-based approach to nursing practice.
8.	Facilitate interprofessional and intraprofessional communication among students and all members of the health care team.
9.	Supervise and assist students with providing nursing care while monitoring and assessing students’ progress with meeting clinical practice expectations.
10.	Collaborate with nursing staff and other health care providers in gaining assistance and access to learning experiences for the students.
11.	Foster reflection and discussion about clinical learning among students during post clinical conferences
12.	Participate in weekly email communication with Course Faculty and provide a brief update and/or identify any concerns about students’ experiences and clinical progress. 
13.	Provide students with ongoing verbal feedback about their progress meeting the clinical practice expectations for the course. 
14.	Provide written midterm and online written final clinical evaluations of each student that highlights their learning and progress with meeting the clinical practice expectations for the clinical placement.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
"Qualifications:
1. Interest in clinical teaching and working with novice nursing students.
2. Minimum of 2-3 years of current and relevant clinical experience (adult acute care nursing).
3. Current registration with the College of Nurses of Ontario as a Registered Nurse or Registered Nurse in the Extended Class. 
4. BScN required; MN will be considered an asset.
5. Previous experience in clinical instructing or as a preceptor is an asset.

Note to Graduate Students:
If you are a graduate student and you accept the position, you will agree to the following:
“I confirm that I will be registered as a University of Toronto student or PDF on the date that this appointment begins. I understand that if I should cease to be registered as a University of Toronto student or PDF during the period of this appointment, for any reason other than convocation, I must immediately notify my supervisor, and my appointment may be terminated.”

job_title: Interdisciplinary Special Topics - The Happy Mind: Scientific Perspectives on Wellness
application_procedure: Please submit applications via the Arts and Science TA System: https://taships.iit.artsci.utoronto.ca/new/postings
duties:
NEW271H1F  – Explore the science of how to cultivate a Happy Mind. This course will merge cutting-edge research from cognitive neuroscience, psychology, and contemplative traditions to investigate what it means to live a fulfilling life. Students will engage with scientific models of well-being, including computational neuroscience models, computational psychiatry, and the neuroscience of emotions. They will study how the mind constructs its reality through predictions, emotions, and habits, examining both the promises and perils of these processes.

DUTIES: Holding office hours; consulting with the course instructors; advising students about and marking assignments; and attending in person lectures.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: The candidate should be familiar with topics and content addressed in the course, particularly in relation to models and theories related to mindfulness, meditation, cognitive neuroscience and wellbeing.
qualifications_preferred: Preference will be given to applicants with an understanding of, or engaged in research related to, mindfulness meditation, and/or contemplative practices.
tutorial: Lectures: Thursdays 10:00 AM - 1:00 PM [Note: the delivery mode is currently In Person and the successful applicant will need to be available to attend lectures].

CIs are required to complete all on-boarding and orientation activities required by the faculty as well as the clinical placement site prior to the start of the placement in preparation for their clinical teaching role. Ongoing support will be provided throughout the term by Course Faculty, the Undergraduate Clinical Resource Faculty, and the Clinical Education Office. Applicants should note that commitment to the role for each scheduled shift for the entire term is needed for consistency in the development, assessment, and evaluation of nursing students.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Duties and Responsibilities:                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               1.	Complete the asynchronous CI orientation learning modules as required and attend the in-person Faculty-led CI orientation for NUR365.
2.	Complete all on-boarding and orientation required by the University as well as the clinical placement site prior to the first clinical shift.
3.	Familiarize themselves with and uphold all faculty and University policies related to clinical placements (e.g., CI and Student Absences, Professional Behaviour). 
4.	Attend all clinical shifts as scheduled. 
a.	Personal obligations (e.g. attending conferences, vacations, or appointments) are to be scheduled outside of the clinical shifts. 
b.	In the case of extenuating circumstances (e.g. illness and/or bereavement) - CIs are required to notify the Clinical Education Office with the dates as soon as possible. CIs may also be asked to assist the Clinical Education Office to arrange a possible replacement instructor. 
5.	Prepare patient assignments prior to students’ arrival on the nursing unit, reflective of the students’ level of expertise.
6.	Facilitate students’ application of theory related to foundational therapeutic, relational, and health assessment skills.
a.	Note: Students are expected to apply learning from the classroom and lab settings each week during their clinical shifts. This is done through practising the learned assessments and skills as part of the nursing care provided, as well as engaging in active discussions about the learning with the CI and clinical group. 
7.	Assist with and assess the students’ preparation for their clinical activities with attention to integration of nursing, pathophysiological, and therapeutic concepts.
8.	Encourage an inquiring, theory, and evidence-informed approach to nursing practice.
9.	Facilitate interprofessional and intraprofessional communication among students and all members of the health care team.
10.	Directly supervise and assist students as they relate to and provide care for older persons, while also monitoring and assessing students’ progress with meeting the clinical practice expectations. 
11.	Collaborate with nursing staff in gaining assistance and access to learning experiences for the students.
12.	Foster reflection and critical discussion about clinical learning among students during weekly post-clinical conferences.
13.	Participate in weekly email communication with Course Faculty and provide a brief update and/or identify any concerns about students’ experiences and clinical progress. 
14.	Provide students with ongoing verbal feedback about their progress with meeting the clinical practice expectations for the course. 
15.	Provide written midterm and final online evaluations incorporating feedback from all clinical shifts.
16.	Arrange and facilitate a short 1:1 virtual meeting to review each students’ final evaluation within a week of the final clinical shift.

job_title:
NEW106H1F: Science, Health and Social Justice
NEW116H1S: Science and Global Threats
application_procedure:
Applicants should submit a detailed letter of application; an updated curriculum vitae; names and contact information (email and phone) for two referees or two reference letters; evidence of teaching in the relevant area, including student evaluations if available by July 14, 2025. 

Applications should be sent to the New College Program Administrator.

Email: nc.hiring@utoronto.ca. 

Application materials must be submitted via email and not through the University of Toronto job board. Late or incomplete applications will not be considered.
duties:
NEW106H1F & NEW116H1S are two of ten small interdisciplinary seminars comprising the first-year foundational program, New One: Learning without Borders. The courses reflect the program’s defining theme, “learning without borders,” by exploring a locally relevant issue through a transnational lens, building students’ capacities as critically reflective learners, emphasizing creative pedagogy and interdisciplinarity, engaging the perspectives of community members and senior students; and fostering student development overall.

NEW106H1F: How can scientific knowledge and research be mobilized to impact individual and global health? How is health impacted by social, racial and economic inequalities? This course explores scientific research and practice with special attention to the translation of scientific knowledge in the public sphere, and its ability to inform policies, practices and laws. Students have the opportunity to meet with clinician-scientists, policy-makers, and other professionals connected to the health care system.

NEW116H1S: What is the role of science in addressing current global threats? What are the possibilities and the limitations of scientific research and knowledge in tackling complex problems such as climate change, pandemics and pollution? In this course, students explore these questions by examining case studies, meeting with specialists in various scientific fields, and engaging in research on a topic of their own choice.

New One courses meet for 3 hours each week.  A portion of those sessions will occasionally be allocated to “Learning Labs.”  All students in the program come together in these Learning Labs to engage in joint activities and explore issues that are common to the four topics.   Both in seminars and Learning Labs, students will experience a variety of ways of learning (through, for example, guest lectures, group work, workshops, field trips to local community organizations, and panels of senior students sharing their experience and insights).

Duties
1. Planning and teaching the seminar course, grading and giving feedback on assignments, providing office hours for academic counseling of students
2. Liaising with the program coordinator and other New One instructors to coordinate and design assignments, plan plenary sessions and evaluate the program.   
3. Incorporating guest speakers and field trips into the course with administrative support from the program coordinator and assistant. 
4. Participating in and occasionally leading the activities of the plenary sessions.

department: New College - Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health
application_procedure: Please submit applications via the Arts and Science TA System: https://taships.iit.artsci.utoronto.ca/new/postings
duties:
BPM214H1 - Explores how Socially Engaged Buddhism has developed in response to global conversations on systemic oppression, climate justice, equity, decolonization, and trauma. We examine the roots of Engaged Buddhism in countries such as Vietnam, China & Taiwan, Sri Lanka, Thailand, and India, and its transformation into a global movement. Themes include Buddhist environmental activism, and Buddhist protest movements, along with research on the application of Buddhist teachings in healthcare, education, business, and the criminal justice system.

DUTIES:
Holding virtual office hours; consulting with the course instructor; advising students about and marking assignments; and may include attending/viewing online lectures.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: The candidate should be familiar with topics and content addressed in the course, particularly in relation to the practices and theories of meditation and mindfulness.
qualifications_preferred: Preference will be given to applicants with an understanding of, or engaged in research related to, Buddhist Studies and/or the interactions between Buddhism and Psychology.
tutorial: Lectures: Wednesdays 10:00 AM - 1:00 PM [Note: the course delivery mode is currently Online Synchronous]

department: New College - Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health
application_procedure: Please submit applications via the Arts and Science TA System: https://taships.iit.artsci.utoronto.ca/new/postings
duties:
BPM232H1: An overview of the encounter between Buddhism and psychology over the last century, with cross-disciplinary study of topics such as self, embodiment, impermanence, suffering, liberation, and insight. We explore how (and why) scientists, psychologists, and Buddhist reformers have reinterpreted Buddhism as “science” and how Buddhist contemplative practices such as mindfulness or compassion training have been transformed and promoted by modern psychology.

DUTIES:
Holding office hours; consulting with the course instructor; advising students about and marking assignments; and may include attending/viewing lectures.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: The candidate should be familiar with topics and content addressed in the course, particularly in relation to the practices and theories of meditation and mindfulness.
qualifications_preferred: Preference will be given to applicants with an understanding of, or engaged in research related to, Buddhist Studies and/or the interactions between Buddhism and Psychology.
tutorial: Lectures: Wednesdays 5:00 PM - 8:00 PM [Note: the course delivery mode is currently In Person]

department: New College - Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health
application_procedure: Please submit applications via the Arts and Science TA System: https://taships.iit.artsci.utoronto.ca/new/postings
duties:
BPM335H1: An overview of scientific research on the psychological and neurophysiological effects of meditation. We explore the effects of different meditation styles on brain structure, brain activity, neurochemistry and other biological processes. Effects of meditation on mental health, pain, social behavior, aging, memory, and cardiovascular function are also a major focus. The use of meditation in the treatment and prevention of illness is critically reviewed.

DUTIES:
Holding  office hours; consulting with the course instructor; advising students about and marking assignments; and may include attending/viewing lectures.

qualifications_preferred: Preference will be given to applicants with an understanding of, or engaged in research related to, Buddhist Studies and/or the interactions between Buddhism and Psychology.
tutorial: Lectures: Mondays 10:00 AM - 1:00 PM [Note: the course delivery mode is currently In Person]

job_title: Buddhist Perspectives on Current Social Issues
department: New College - Buddhism, Psychology and Mental Health
application_procedure: Please submit applications via the Arts and Science TA System: https://taships.iit.artsci.utoronto.ca/new/postings
duties:
BPM381H1S: Explores teachings and principles in Buddhist canonical sources and considers their application to a wide range of social, political, and environmental crises we are facing today, including climate justice, systemic racism, burnout and mental health. We explore how Buddhist teachings are applied and adapted across different sectors of society including healthcare, education and business.

We examine the roots of Engaged Buddhism in countries such as Vietnam, China & Taiwan, Sri Lanka, Thailand, and India, and its transformation into a global movement. Themes include Buddhist environmental activism, and Buddhist protest movements, along with research on the application of Buddhist teachings in healthcare, education, business, and the criminal justice system.

DUTIES:
Holding virtual office hours; consulting with the course instructor; advising students about and marking assignments; and may include attending/viewing online lectures.

qualifications_preferred: Preference will be given to applicants with an understanding of, or engaged in research related to, Buddhist Studies and/or the interactions between Buddhism and Psychology.

duties:
BPM232H1: An overview of the encounter between Buddhism and psychology over the last century, with cross-disciplinary study of topics such as self, embodiment, impermanence, suffering, liberation, and insight. We explore how (and why) scientists, psychologists, and Buddhist reformers have reinterpreted Buddhism as “science” and how Buddhist contemplative practices such as mindfulness or compassion training have been transformed and promoted by modern psychology.

duties:
BPM335H1: An overview of scientific research on the psychological and neurophysiological effects of meditation. We explore the effects of different meditation styles on brain structure, brain activity, neurochemistry and other biological processes. Effects of meditation on mental health, pain, social behavior, aging, memory, and cardiovascular function are also a major focus. The use of meditation in the treatment and prevention of illness is critically reviewed.

application_procedure:
Please send the following to md.foundations@utoronto.ca before closing date (July 20, 2025 at 11:59 pm):
-	Subject line: Assistant Invigilator Positions (CUPE 3902)
-	Up-to-date resume (cover letter is optional)
-	Student number
-	Confirmation of availability for the period outlined above
Incomplete applications will not be considered.
duties:
Responsibilities include, but are not limited to, the following: 
•	Supervising in-person assessments (i.e., Mastery Exercises and Progress Tests) across the MD Program; some remote shifts may be required 
•	Through active invigilation, maintain the integrity of assessments by adhering to the MD program, faculty, and university policies and procedures 
•	Maintaining confidentiality and security of student and assessment information 
•	Monitoring test/exam time allotments 
•	Handling student concerns/problems and referring to MD Program staff where appropriate 
•	Reporting anomalous situations using a Quercus form
•	Verifying student identification 
•	Making assessment-related announcements to students 
•	In certain cases, invigilators may assist in transporting backup laptops between the Medical Sciences Building and the Exam Center at 255 McCaul Street or another exam site on the St. George campus.
•	Invigilators are required to attend an in-person orientation session for a mock Mastery Exercise in the last week of August 2025.
qualifications:
•	Applicants must be registered for the 2025-2026 Academic Year as students pursuing a graduate degree with the School of Graduate Studies at the University of Toronto  
•	Applicants must be available for in-person invigilation shifts between August 25, 2025, and August 23, 2026 
•	Experience in invigilating tests/exams is an asset 
•	Understanding and ability to apply relevant University and government policies, procedures, and legislation

We explore how Buddhist teachings are applied and adapted across different sectors of society including healthcare, education and business.

application_procedure:

duties:
CSE270H1 – An introduction to issues and questions arising from the field of 'community engagement'. Explores the meaning, practices and implications of/for 'community' and 'community (dis)engagement' from multiple perspectives (e.g. the State and its agencies, institutional power, colonial discourse, communities of embodied difference, etc.) Takes a multi-media and arts-based approach to examining self-care from an anti-colonial perspective of central importance in the practice and pedagogy of critical equity and solidarity in the collective struggle for freedom and transformation.

DUTIES: Normal duties related to the design and teaching of a university credit course, including preparation and delivery of course content; development, administration and marking of assignments, tests and exams; calculation and submission of grades; and holding regular office hours.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Completed or nearly completed Ph.D. (or equivalent) required. with an academic background in areas related to the specific course.  Academic background in social justice theory/praxis, community engaged teaching and learning, and familiarity with anti-oppressive pedagogies.
qualifications_preferred: Experience teaching equity and social justice issues in a university setting is preferred.
tutorial:
Lectures: Wednesdays 1:00 PM - 3:00 PM [Note: the course delivery mode is currently In Person]. 

Tutorials: Wednesdays 12:00 PM - 1:00 PM and 3:00 PM - 4:00 PM.

Engages with a variety of theoretical frameworks including anti-homophobia education, critical pedagogy, critical race theory, decolonizing knowledges, and intersectionality. Includes an overview of educational activist projects.

job_title: Introduction to Critical Equity and Solidarity Studies
department: New College - Critical Studies in Equity and Solidarity
application_procedure: Please submit applications via the Arts and Science TA System: https://taships.iit.artsci.utoronto.ca/new/postings
duties:
CSE240H1 – An interdisciplinary intersectional interrogation and examination of systemic inequity, structural oppression and social justice in local and global contexts. Provides a foundation for studies in critical equity and solidarity through a concentrated focus on theory and practice as it relates to major concepts, historical perspectives, key debates, lived experience and radical grassroots community resistance to inequity and oppression. Introduces critical equity as a theoretical framework through which to approach social relations of race, ethnicity, class, gender, sexuality and disability and as a site for thinking through formations of solidarity and transformative social change. The concept of self-defense articulated historically by the Black Panther Party for Self-Defense among others is a key component.

DUTIES: 
Preparing and conducting two weekly tutorials ; Holding office hours; consulting with the course instructor; advising students about and marking course assignments; may include attending lectures.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: The candidate must be familiar with historical and theoretical foundations of inequities and have some background in community organizing.
qualifications_preferred: Preference will be given to applicants engaged in related research. Teaching experience facilitating small groups is desirable.

duties:
IFP100Y1Y – Surveys the development of human societies from their origins to the present using examples from across the world.  Topics may include the environment; cultural development and interaction; the creation and nature of belief systems; political, economic and social structures; gender relations; and the relationship between global patterns and local developments. NOTE: the theme in 2025/26 explores how food & commodities impacted world history. Some of the topics explored include:   beer, corn, spices, fur, sugar, coffee, tea, cotton, and water. 

DUTIES
• Preparing and conducting one to two 1.5 hour in-person tutorials each week
• Holding office hours
• Attending lectures and consulting with the Instructor and/or Lead TA
• Attending meetings set by the Instructor and/or Lead TA
• Advising students about and marking course assignments.

application_procedure: Please submit applications via the Arts and Science TA System: https://taships.iit.artsci.utoronto.ca/new/postings
duties:
JQR360H1S – Examines the Canadian population census through the experience of diasporic groups in Canada. Approaches the census as a statistical tool, an historical source and an ideological project of citizenship and nationalism.  Uses census data to explore mathematical and statistical concepts and to integrate numerical ways of thinking with qualitative analysis (Jointly sponsored by African Studies, Diaspora and Transnational Studies, Caribbean Studies, Critical Studies in Equity and Solidarity, and Latin American Studies).   

DUTIES: In-person or online (Zoom) teaching of skills-based labs on quantitative research methods to support lab assignments in the course, using MS Excel and online databases. Recording of skilled-based labs. 

Holding office hours 

Consulting with and attending benchmarking sessions with the Instructor 

Advising students about and marking of reading-based responses, assignments, and lab reports.

May involve attending lectures
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Ability to teach quantitative research methods to students with little or no background in statistics (e.g. data analysis in Excel; creating graphs and charts in Excel; basic statistical analysis; and use of demographic surveys in research and policy); and familiarity with history and theory relating to the course and experience with social science reading and writing assignments required.
qualifications_preferred: Engagement in research related to the course and previous experience as a student in the course would be an asset.

application_procedure: "Please click on the "How to Apply" tab on our website: https://bloomberg.nursing.utoronto.ca/careers/clinical-instructor-positions/#ApplyClinical
duties:
The Lawrence Bloomberg Faculty of Nursing Program provides a full-time, two-year, second entry baccalaureate nursing education. Given that nursing is a practice-based profession, we believe that clinical experience is a vital and integral component of the curriculum, providing students with hands-on opportunities to actively apply classroom learning to ‘real life’ nursing practice under the supervision and support of a clinical teacher. Clinical Instructors (CIs) play an important role in facilitating student learning to further develop students’ knowledge, skill, and judgement. CIs are expected to support both students and preceptors in placements. CIs should be flexible and prepared to utilize additional learning modalities such as simulation and virtual clinical learning in the event a clinical day is cancelled by the organization. CIs will work closely with the Clinical Education Office and Course Faculty to develop and share resources to support the continuity of clinical teaching and student learning. CIs are required to complete all on-boarding and orientation activities required by the faculty as well as the clinical placement site prior to the start of the placement in preparation for their clinical teaching role. Ongoing support will be provided throughout the term by Course Faculty, the Undergraduate Clinical Resource Faculty, and the Clinical Education Office.  Applicants should note that commitment to the role for the entire term is needed for consistency in the development, assessment, and evaluation of nursing students.                                                                Duties and Responsibilities:                  1.  Complete the asynchronous CI orientation learning modules as required and attend the in-person Faculty-led CI orientation for NUR461.                             2.  Complete all on-boarding and orientation required by the University as well as the clinical placement sites.  
3. Familiarize themselves with and uphold all faculty and university policies related to clinical placements (e.g., CI and Student Absences, Professional Behavior).  
4.  Assist students in creating clinical learning objectives for their respective community placements that are reflective of course outcomes, clinical practice expectations and students’ level of learning.  
5. Assist in the delivery of a three-hour primary skills lab for students, in collaboration with faculty (Friday September 5th, 2025 - times to be confirmed).  
6. Facilitate an in-person four hours community simulation (dates/times to be confirmed).
7. Encourage an inquiring, theory, and evidence-based approach to nursing practice. 
8. Facilitate interprofessional and intraprofessional communication among students and all members of the health care team. 
9. Collaborate with the NUR461 course instructors to plan the weekly virtual clinical discussion sessions in alignment with the course theoretical concepts.  
10. Prepare for and facilitate a weekly online, synchronous two-hour clinical discussion with the students, reflecting on virtual case scenarios completed by the students and building on existing clinical experiences.  
11. Monitor student performance and assess student progress with meeting the clinical practice expectations for the course.   
12. Participate in weekly email communication with Course Faculty and provide a brief update and / or identify any concerns about students’ experiences and clinical progress.  
13. Ensure ongoing communication with students, preceptors, and course faculty.  
14. Provide students with ongoing verbal feedback about their progress in meeting the clinical expectations for the course. 
15. Collaborate with course faculty throughout the term as needed to deal with student clinical placement issues. 
16. Complete an online written final clinical evaluation of each student incorporating feedback from all clinical shifts that highlights their learning and progress in meeting the clinical practice expectations for the community placement.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Qualifications:
1. Excellent understanding of primary health care principles and the social determinants of health. 
2. Professional nursing experience in public health and community health, including rural and/or underserved settings.
3. Current registration with the College of Nurses of Ontario as a Registered Nurse or Registered Nurse in the Extended Class. 
4. Current membership in the Registered Nurses Association of Ontario (RNAO) is preferred. 
5. Master's degree in Nursing or equivalent is preferred; BScN is required. 
6. Previous teaching experience will be considered an asset.                                                                                                                7. Excellent facilitation, analytical, and written and oral communication skills.                                                                                                                 8. Competent in MS Office applications.                             9. Experience using online Learning Management Systems.
Note to Graduate Students:
If you are a graduate student and you accept the position, you will agree to the following:
“I confirm that I will be registered as a University of Toronto student or PDF on the date that this appointment begins. I understand that if I should cease to be registered as a University of Toronto student or PDF during the period of this appointment, for any reason other than convocation, I must immediately notify my supervisor, and my appointment may be terminated.”

application_procedure:
Application information is available at https://www.statistics.utoronto.ca/employment-opportunities/cupe-positions-unit-1. The deadline to submit your application is July 9, 2025. For more information, you may contact:

Angela Niazmand
Undergraduate and TA Administrator
Department of Statistical Sciences
University of Toronto
700 University Avenue
Ontario Power Building - 9160-6
Toronto, ON M5G 1Z5
www.statistics.utoronto.ca
E-mail: jobapps.statistics@utoronto.ca
duties:
As part of the English Language Learning (ELL) Initiative in Arts and Science, the Lead TA will work with the ELL Coordinators to support Course Instructors and train regular course SIAs in ACT371H1. The LTA will perform the following duties:

o	Regular 1:1 training and collaboration with ELL coordinator or other ELL faculty
o	Participate in cross-disciplinary lunch and discussion sessions for Lead TAs
o	Meet with ELL coordinators and course instructors to plan course assignments and tutorials
o	Design and lead training sessions for course TAs on topics such as marking assignments and presentations, as well as planning tutorial activities integrating ACT371H1 course content to scholarly reading, professional writing, oral presentation, discussion skills, and intercultural communication
o	Develop and/or adapt existing resources on reading, oral presentation, and writing instruction for course instructors, TAs, and students
o	Communicate regularly with course instructors, ELL coordinators, and others to coordinate activities
o	Collect and summarize data (e.g., surveys, student writing samples, etc.)

Duties of this position shall be performed on the St. George Campus.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Required:
o   Evidence of writing competence in their discipline. 
o   Applicants must submit a writing sample, appended to the end of their CV. 
o   The writing sample should provide evidence of writing and communication skills, and not be technical in nature (e.g. journal or journal-like paper for your respective discipline would not be appropriate).
o	Personal or academic writing sample are acceptable, provided they meet the criterion above. 
o	Writing sample should not exceed 5 pages in length (single-spaced, size 12 font). No minimum length. 

o   Current PhD student with experience in quantitative analysis and significant experience in research writing and/or consulting. Does not have to be enrolled in a Statistics program.
o   At least two years' experience as a course TA, whether leading tutorials, labs, or in-class instruction; or grading
o   Excellent oral and interpersonal skills, particularly the ability to work effectively with and show tact when communicating with course instructors and TAs
o   Strong administrative skills, including scheduling meetings and planning, time management, meeting multiple deadlines, and documenting work
o   Able to prioritize tasks
o   Strong facilitation and presentation skills and/or experience leading workshops
o   Intercultural competence, especially an understanding of the issues faced by multilingual and international students
qualifications_preferred:
Required:
o   Evidence of writing competence in their discipline. 
o   Applicants must submit a writing sample, appended to the end of their CV. 
o   The writing sample should provide evidence of writing and communication skills, and not be technical in nature (e.g. journal or journal-like paper for your respective discipline would not be appropriate).
o	Personal or academic writing sample are acceptable, provided they meet the criterion above. 
o	Writing sample should not exceed 5 pages in length (single-spaced, size 12 font). No minimum length. 

o   Current PhD student with experience in quantitative analysis and significant experience in research writing and/or consulting. Does not have to be enrolled in a Statistics program.

o   Able to prioritize tasks
o   Strong facilitation and presentation skills and/or experience leading workshops
o   Intercultural competence, especially an understanding of the issues faced by multilingual and international students

job_title: Introduction to Critical Equity and Solidarity Studies
department: New College - Critical Studies in Equity and Solidarity
application_procedure:
Applicants should submit a hiring package containing detailed letter of application; an updated curriculum vitae; names and contact information (email and phone) for two referees or two reference letters; evidence of teaching in the relevant area, including student evaluations if available by June 20, 2025.

Applications should be sent to the New College Program Administrator. All materials must be in one document (i.e., PDF, word document).

Email: nc.hiring@utoronto.ca. 

Application materials must be submitted via email and not through the University of Toronto job board. Late or incomplete applications will not be considered.
duties:
CSE240H1 - An interdisciplinary intersectional interrogation and examination of systemic inequity, structural oppression and social justice in local and global contexts. Provides a foundation for studies in critical equity and solidarity through a concentrated focus on theory and practice as it relates to major concepts, historical perspectives, key debates, lived experience and radical grassroots community resistance to inequity and oppression. Introduces critical equity as a theoretical framework through which to approach social relations of race, ethnicity, class, gender, sexuality and disability and as a site for thinking through formations of solidarity and transformative social change. The concept of self-defense articulated historically by the Black Panther Party for Self-Defense among others is a key component.

DUTIES: Normal duties related to the design and teaching of a university credit course, including preparation and delivery of course content; development, administration and marking of assignments, tests and exams; calculation and submission of grades; and holding regular office hours.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Completed or nearly completed Ph.D. (or equivalent) required. The candidate should have a background in critical equity studies and intersectional theories of social justice, as well as a familiarity with anti-oppressive pedagogies.
qualifications_preferred: Teaching experience at the university level in Equity Studies or related social justice fields is preferred.
tutorial: Lectures: Tuesdays and Thursdays 3:00 PM - 5:00 PM [Note: the course delivery mode is currently Online Synchronous]

job_title: Assessing Global Change: Science and the Environment
application_procedure:
Please submit an application on https://taships.iit.artsci.utoronto.ca/env/login.

Applications should include: i) a letter of application, explaining why you are qualified for the course(s) to which you are applying, and ii) a CV (including academic and applied environmental experience). 

Please note: The letter of application should be combined with your CV, and uploaded as a single file, where you are asked to upload your CV. Applicants are requested not to apply to TA positions for which they do not have the qualifications listed under "Minimum Qualifications".
duties: Duties include preparing and leading tutorial sessions, grading assignments, tests and final assessments, responding to student email requests, and general assistance.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: University of Toronto graduate students who have completed one year of graduate study with emphasis placed on scientific training, particularly related to the environment, and the perspective scientists bring to the understanding and resolution of environmental concerns having global implications: atmospheric systems and climate change, the biosphere and conservation of biodiversity.
qualifications_preferred: Previous experience in this course or similar course, with the ability to lead small group discussions.

duties: - Leading discussion-based tutorials – Tracking attendance and grading participation in tutorial - Grading assignments, in-class tests and an exam – Attending weekly TA meetings - Invigilating in-class tests – Office hours for academic counselling of students – Communication with tutorial students (email/quercus) - Other duties as assigned by the instructor.  Given the size of the class and the number of teaching assistants, attendance at the weekly TA meeting is mandatory and a requirement for the position.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.

qualifications_preferred: Background in European history, political science or political thought

job_title: Hitler and Stalin Today - Lead TA
department: Munk School of Global Affairs and Public Policy
application_procedure: All individuals interested in this position must submit an updated Curriculum Vitae and Cover Letter to the Undergrad Coordinator - Munk School of Global Affairs & Public undergraduatecoordinator.munkschool@utoronto.ca. Please indicate in your Cover Letter whether you will be available for an RAship in Fall 2025, as preference will be given to those who can.
duties:
The lead teaching assistant will lead and manage the teaching assistants for this large, introductory course so as to ensure that students are supported and engaged.  

Their responsibilities will include ensuring proper and timely communication among the course instructors, teaching assistants, and students. The lead teaching assistant will help devise tutorial learning strategies and outlines; run weekly meetings for the teaching assistants at which they address the tutorial strategies and content to help ensure consistency and relevance; provide one-to-one support for teaching assistants as necessary; ensure consistency in grading across tutorials; help manage communications systems and processes with students; share key course announcements from the course instructor with the class; organize and assist with invigilation of tests and exams; and other duties as assigned by the instructor.  

This is a leadership position that requires problem solving and a thoughtful approach to working with peers and students.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Must be currently enrolled in a Social Sciences or Humanities PhD program at the University of Toronto, with at least three academic years of teaching assistant experience.  

Experience in a leadership role among peers.  

Demonstrated excellence in teaching and in engaged, empathetic pedagogy.
qualifications_preferred: Background in European history, political science or political thought.

application_procedure: This job is posted in accordance with the CUPE 3902 Unit 1 Collective Agreement. Positions posted here are open to Graduate Students in the School of Graduate Studies and Postdoctoral Fellows. Preference in hiring shall be given to Graduate Students enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies of the University of Toronto or those who have made application to be enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies of the University of Toronto. Visit the Lawrence Bloomberg Faculty of Nursing website for instructions on how to apply for Teaching Assistant positions https://bloomberg.nursing.utoronto.ca/current-students/teaching-assistantships/. The University of Toronto is strongly committed to diversity within its community and especially welcomes applications from racialized persons / persons of colour, women, Indigenous / Aboriginal People of North America, persons with disabilities, LGBTQ2S+ persons, and others who may contribute to the further diversification of ideas. Candidates who are members of Indigenous, Black, racialized and LGBTQ2S+ communities, persons with disabilities, and other equity seeking groups are encouraged to apply, and their lived experience shall be taken into consideration as applicable to the position. The University strives to be an equitable and inclusive community, and proactively seeks to increase diversity among its community members. Our values regarding equity and diversity are linked with our unwavering commitment to excellence in the pursuit of our academic mission. The University is committed to the principles of the Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities Act (AODA). As such, we strive to make our recruitment, assessment and selection processes as accessible as possible and provide accommodations as required for applicants with disabilities. If you require any accommodation at any point during the application and hiring process, please contact uoft.careers@utoronto.ca. During employment, to request accommodation from the University, contact the supervisor or department chair and/or Health & Wellbeing Programs & Services at hwb@utoronto.ca. For more information about accommodations at UofT, please visit our Accommodation webpage. Duties of this position shall be performed at the campus on which the position is located. Where the duties are intended to be performed at another location, such other location will be specified in the posting.

application_procedure: Applicants must submit a cover letter, C.V. or resume, and a list of references by July 16 2025. Applicant cover letters should indicate up to three PART modules they are most suited to lead. Applications should be sent via email to the Robert Gillespie Academic Skills Centre at academicskills.utm@utoronto.ca with the subject title: PART Unit 1 Job Posting.
duties: As a Teaching Assistant for the Robert Gillespie Academic Skills Centre’s (RGASC) Program for Accessing Research Training (PART), the TA will design and lead a select number of modules related to introductory research skills. The TA will perform the following duties: develop and instruct assigned in-person and/or online asynchronous and/or synchronous modules, mark assignments, track module attendance, and answer module-specific student inquiries. The TA will work and meet regularly with the Faculty member directing the progam and RGASC staff. Modules to be facilitated by successful applicants include: Conducting Interviews; Descriptive Statistics; Inferential Statistics; Interdisciplinary Special Topic; Lab Safety and Conduct in Labs; Leading a Focus Group; Special Topics in STEM; Special Topics in the Humanities; Special Topics in the Social Sciences; Survey Techniques; Transcribing and Qualitative Coding
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Applicants must be currently enrolled as a Master or PhD graduate student at the University of Toronto. Applicants should have at least two years of experience as a Teaching Assistant at the University of Toronto and demonstrate strong facilitation and presentation skills and/or experience leading/facilitating workshops (e.g., tutorials, practicals, courses, etc.). Applicants must have experience conducting qualitative and/or quantitative research at the graduate level. Applicants must have the ability to work effectively with and show tact when communicating with PART administrators, students, and other Teaching Assistants.
qualifications_preferred: Preference will be given to candidates with experience developing and leading PART modules and/or teaching experience in an undergraduate research methods course. Completion of a graduate-level research methods course is an asset. Experience using Quercus is also an asset.

application_procedure: To apply, please email your CV and contact info of two teaching references to unit1app@math.toronto.edu with the subject line "application for MAT292F".
duties: This job is for an instructor in a large undergraduate course with multiple sections which may or may not have a designated course coordinator.  Each instructor will perform tasks including but not limited to: lecturing, conducting office hours, preparing class materials / tutorials / tests / exams, grading assignments / exams, communicating with TAs.  The exact mix will be determined by the course coordinator (if applicable) and may change as the situation evolves. You are also expected to attend the orientation meetings and course organizational meetings.  Additional duties may be required as directed by the Course Coordinator (if applicable), the Undergraduate Administrator or the Associate Chair, Undergraduate.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         If there is no designated coordinator, there is an expectation that the different sections of a multi-section course will function similarly: they will normally have the same syllabus and assessment plan, and will have common midterm exams and final exam. Problem sets and quizzes should be common, or at least similar/interchangeable, and should operate at a similar level with a similar approach.  In addition, all instructors are expected to work together with the other instructors in the course and to collaborate in creating the syllabus, determining the course structure, and creating and marking the final assessment.    Normally, classes, tests and tutorials will be conducted in person.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Senior PhD student in mathematics (entered PhD program in 2021, or earlier) or Current PDF with a PhD degree in Mathematics working in Mathematics or a related field. Knowledge of course material, being responsible and able to keep deadlines are essential. Previous experience as a Course Instructor or Teaching Assistant, in the course (or its equivalent) is an asset.

job_title: Introduction to Evolution and Evolutionary Genetics- Lab TA
application_procedure: apply through https://cupeha.utm.utoronto.ca/dept/umbio/app/ta
duties: Typical duties may include but are not limited to: preparing tests/labs/exams, attending meetings with supervisor, setting up laboratory materials, demonstrating in lab/seminar, demonstrating equipment, consulting with students, marking quizzes/ tests/oral presentations, marking exams, invigilating
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: A 4-year degree in Biology with appropriate background for the course to be demonstrated. Must be available to attend on-site during scheduled PRA sessions and weekly one hour TA meetings (Tuesdays 11:15am).
qualifications_preferred: Preferred Qualifications include: academic qualifications, enrolment as a graduate student, previous TA experience, suitability for the position and appropriate background in the subject/specialty within the Department of Biology
salery: $52.97 per hour (+4% vacation pay) Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

job_title: Writing in Business and the Professions for Rotman Commerce Students
application_procedure: Please submit a cover letter and curriculum vitae by 11:59pm EDT on July 21, 2025 to hr.innis@utoronto.ca. The subject line should include the position type (TA or course instructor) and the course code. For filing purposes, we ask that applicants applying to multiple positions please send separate emails for each position you are applying to.
duties: Leading up to two tutorials each week, meeting with students one-on-one, grading assignments, and answering student queries through email.**Please note, the delivery method for this course is currently in person. In keeping with current circumstances, the course delivery method may change as determined by the Faculty or the College.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: University of Toronto graduate student who has completed one year of graduate study and who has a demonstrated scholarly expertise in English literature, academic writing, professional writing, and/or rhetoric. Extensive experience marking and annotating undergraduate essays, total fluency in both spoken and written English, and a thorough knowledge of standard English grammar are essential.
qualifications_preferred: Some experience with teaching courses in or marking papers in professional writing and/or report writing would be an advantage. Experience teaching business/commerce/management students would be an advantage.
tutorial: Lecture: Mondays 3-5pm; Tutorial: Tuesdays and Thursdays 1-2pm

job_title: Introduction to Medicine, Concepts, Patients, and Communities - 1, Concepts, Patients, and Communities -2, Life Cyle
application_procedure:
Please submit the following documents to Dr. Kristina Lisk by July 7th, 2025, using the MS form linked below. If you have any issues submitting your application using the linked form, please email it directly to Kristina.lisk@utoronto.ca.

•	Cover letter, including a statement of teaching experience(s) and previous student evaluations, if applicable
•	Updated CV
•	MS application form: https://forms.office.com/r/MaGTbjM1J7
duties:
Basic Training / Attendance at onboarding meeting with Course Instructor.
Leading in-person, hands-on, human anatomy laboratories that focus on the gross anatomy of the back, thorax, abdomen, pelvis. 
Demonstrating dissection of human cadavers. 
Demonstrating gross anatomy using models, bones, and human cadaveric prosections. 
Meeting with the Course Instructor prior to every in-person laboratory and in-person MAPS session. 
Participating in TA training sessions.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Successful completion of a practical course in human gross anatomy at the University of Toronto or equivalent is required. 

Experience in human cadaveric dissection is required.
qualifications_preferred:
Experience teaching practical human gross anatomy is an asset. 

An MD degree, completed or in progress, from the University of Toronto or equivalent is an asset.
tutorial: Labs are on Tuesdays 9am - 4pm. There is also 1 lab in January held on a Monday 9am - 4pm.

DLS Unit 1 Job Application form (Please submit your information here: https://forms.office.com/r/94cuaqRR5T, then "print to PDF" to save a copy of the submission), 2. Cover letter (this should include a statement on the applicant's background and experience with respect to the posted qualifications), and 3. Current academic CV.
duties: All normal duties related to the design and teaching of a University credit course, including, but not restricted to, preparation and delivery of course content; out-of-class interactions with students via e-mail and regular office hours; development, administration and marking of assignments, tests and exams; calculation and submission of grades; and supervision of TAs/Graders (if any) as required. The instructor is expected to be fully available for the duration of the employment period. (NOTE: The mode of instruction for this course is expected to be in-person. However, if this changes for any reason, as much advance notice as practicable will be given.)
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: PhD student in French literary studies, comparative literature or a related field.  Demonstrated experience with university-level French literature courses including literary theory.  In-depth knowledge of francophone literature from the 19th century to the present period.  (Near-)native spoken & written French competence.
qualifications_preferred: Experience teaching university-level French as a second langauge courses.  (Near-)native spoken English competence.  Demonstrated excellence in this course or a closely related course is preferred.

job_title: Introductory Chemistry I: Structure and Bonding
duties: Candidates are expected to provide oversight to the lab environment, ensuring that all students are working safely, and providing an enhanced learning experience through direct student engagement during their laboratory experiments. Candidates will need to prepare for each experiment by reading the provided materials and attending the training sessions. During the laboratory period, candidates will walk around the lab room(s), observing students as they work and ensuring that all safety protocols are being observed. They will engage with students as they complete their experiments, offering guidance as needed to help students understand the lab procedures, techniques, and concepts.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: A B.Sc. with a major or specialist in chemistry is required for the positions; however, senior undergraduate chemistry students at UTSC who have completed CHMB16H3 and at least one C-level CHM course with a lab may also be considered. Applicants must have excellent foundational knowledge of core chemistry principles and have strong laboratory skills, including basic techniques such as titrations, weighing by difference, solution preparation and preparing calibration curves. Candidates should demonstrate effective teaching assistance skills in a lab setting. Excellent communication and interpersonal skills are essential, as well as the ability to work collaboratively and supportively with students, teaching assistants, and faculty. Preference will be given to candidates enrolled in a Ph.D. in chemistry or related field with prior teaching experience.

job_title: Cohort Capstone Course in Environmental Studies
application_procedure: UTSC: CUPE Hiring Application (utoronto.ca)
duties:
Delivery of online lectures, leading class discussions, updating exams and assignments, marking, marks management, supervision of TA(s), guidance, supervision and management of student teams.
Winter 2026: Lectures: Thursdays from 18:00 - 20:00
https://ttb.utoronto.ca/
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: ESTD17Y is a project-based course centered on environmental problem-solving. The course itself is anchored in decision analysis and\or assessment procedures as applied in business, government, and civil society. Students apply a broad array of inter-related, problem solving, assessment, and analytical methods\tools that are typically associated with sustainable development and\or climate change (SDGs, PIEVC, ICLEI, and ISO31000). To be able to teach the course, the candidate must have a strong background in an applied environmental science, as well as complementary analytical, and team management skills, associated with project supervision. Direct experience teaching and\or applying Project Management would be a definite asset. Because of the encompassing nature of the course, a senior-level PhD candidate in a relevant discipline such as Geography, Forestry, Environmental Studies, Environmental science, and\or Management Science is required.

duties: TA's in this course will be fully responsible for students in the tutorial section(s)  assigned to them. Duties include (but are not limited to):  conducting weekly tutorial sections assigned by the instructor; supporting students in the tutorials during regularly assigned office hours; answering student's email inquiries in an appropriate and timely fashion for students in the assigned tutorial section(s), marking all work (essays, assignments, tests, and final exams) by students in the assigned tutorial sections and recording the resulting grades on Quercus; doing all course readings, participating in training for conducting tutorials; and any other relatable duties assigned by the course instructor. Additional duties may include attending lectures and invigilating tests where applicable.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Minimum MA in Sociology/Criminology or related discipline, or currently accepted or enrolled in the graduate Sociology program; knowledge in the subject area; strong knowledge of the subject matter; TA experience; ability to instruct in writing; demonstrated ability in advising students and helping them learn.  MUST be available to hold/lead Tutorials in person on TUESDAYS
qualifications_preferred: Previous TA experience; having taken this course or a similar course; demonstrated proficiency in the subject area of the course.

duties: The design, preparation and delivery of course content, including teaching lectures; the development and administration of assignments and tests; the marking and grading of student work, and the submission of grades to the College in accordance with established policies and procedures; coordination with the instructors of the other DHU235H1 sections; the maintenance of reasonable hours of student contact outside scheduled classroom hours; and the use of Quercus (the web-based course management system) to communicate grades, announcements, course material and academic resources online.

salery: $9,276.01 (excludes vacation pay) or $10,553.15 (excludes vacation pay) (excludes vacation pay, first Course Instructor Appointment). Please note that should rates stipulated in the collective agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the collective agreement shall prevail.

application_procedure: To apply, please email your CV and contact info of two teaching references to unit1app@math.toronto.edu with the subject line "application for MAT292F".
duties: This job is for an instructor in a large undergraduate course with multiple sections which may or may not have a designated course coordinator.  Each instructor will perform tasks including but not limited to: lecturing, conducting office hours, preparing class materials / tutorials / tests / exams, grading assignments / exams, communicating with TAs.  The exact mix will be determined by the course coordinator (if applicable) and may change as the situation evolves. You are also expected to attend the orientation meetings and course organizational meetings.  Additional duties may be required as directed by the Course Coordinator (if applicable), the Undergraduate Administrator or the Associate Chair, Undergraduate.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         If there is no designated coordinator, there is an expectation that the different sections of a multi-section course will function similarly: they will normally have the same syllabus and assessment plan, and will have common midterm exams and final exam. Problem sets and quizzes should be common, or at least similar/interchangeable, and should operate at a similar level with a similar approach.  In addition, all instructors are expected to work together with the other instructors in the course and to collaborate in creating the syllabus, determining the course structure, and creating and marking the final assessment.    Normally, classes, tests and tutorials will be conducted in person.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Senior PhD student in mathematics (entered PhD program in 2021, or earlier) or Current PDF with a PhD degree in Mathematics working in Mathematics or a related field. Knowledge of course material, being responsible and able to keep deadlines are essential. Previous experience as a Course Instructor or Teaching Assistant, in the course (or its equivalent) is an asset.

department: Munk School of Global Affairs and Public Policy
application_procedure: All individuals interested in this position must submit an updated Curriculum Vitae and Cover Letter and TA evaluations to the Undergrad Coordinator - Munk School of Global Affairs & Public undergraduatecoordinator.munkschool@utoronto.ca.
duties:
– Attending class
 – Marking assignments (essays and exams) 
– Holding tutorials (leading discussion and running exercises) 
– Holding office hours to counsel students 
– Tracking participation 
– Other duties as assigned by the instructor
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Must be currently enrolled in a Social Sciences or Humanities PhD program, or enrolled in the Centre for European and Eurasian Studies, Master of Global Affairs, or Master of Public Policy MA program at the University of Toronto.
qualifications_preferred: Teaching experience and some familiarity with political science (international relations and/or comparative political economy).

department: Munk School of Global Affairs and Public Policy
application_procedure: All individuals interested in this position must submit an updated Curriculum Vitae and Cover Letter and TA evaluations to the Undergrad Coordinator - Munk School of Global Affairs & Public undergraduatecoordinator.munkschool@utoronto.ca.
duties:
- Proactively planning and running assigned tutorial sessions
- Checking-in and coordinating with course instructors regarding tutorial session plans
- Grading assignments, exams, and tutorial participation
- Providing academic feedback to students, including in office hours
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Must be currently enrolled in a Social Sciences or Humanities PhD program, or enrolled in the Centre for European and Eurasian Studies, Master of Global Affairs, or Master of Public Policy MA program (with teaching experience preferred), at the University of Toronto.
qualifications_preferred: A background in the social sciences and/or the liberal arts is preferred. Familiarity with issues of digital technologies is an asset.

job_title: Democracy in Crisis: Democratic Breakdown and Resilience in the 21st century
department: Munk School of Global Affairs and Public Policy
application_procedure: All individuals interested in this position must submit an updated Curriculum Vitae and Cover Letter and TA evaluations to the Undergrad Coordinator - Munk School of Global Affairs & Public undergraduatecoordinator.munkschool@utoronto.ca.
duties:
- Holding tutorials 
- Grading assignments  
- Monitoring Quercus student responses 
- Office hours for academic counselling of students 
- Other duties as assigned by the instructor
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Must be currently enrolled in a Social Sciences or Humanities PhD program, or enrolled in the Centre for European and Eurasian Studies, Master of Global Affairs, or Master of Public Policy MA program (with teaching experience preferred), at the University of Toronto.
qualifications_preferred: Some background in comparative politics/political science preferred

department: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering
application_procedure: Please submit your teaching resume with cover letter as one (1) PDF to for each position you are interested in to ugta.ece@utoronto.ca.  Please label the PDF document using the following format: LastName, FirstName - CI - Course Code.  Messages in the body of the email will not be considered.  Please ONLY include your student number if you are a student. Otherwise UTORID/personnel if you are a Post-Doc. Deadline is July 4, 2025 at 11:59PM.
duties: Deliver lectures in accordance with class schedule and description; supervise TAs (if applicable); evaluate student's work and assign final grades.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Graduate students and post-doctoral fellows who possess and demonstrate expertise in the subject matter and have experience teaching (or serving as a teaching assistant in) in this or a similar course. The successful candidate must demonstrate a track record of professionalism and aptitude for instruction.
qualifications_preferred: Preference given to candidates with strong academic qualifications.  Ph.D. or post-doctoral fellows are preferred. Having repeated relevant experiences teaching (or having served as a teaching assistant) especially in this course offering is a strong asset.

application_procedure: Send a cover letter and CV addressed to the selection committee by e-mail in a PDF format to: cpssljobs.utm@utoronto.ca.
duties: All normal duties related to the design and teaching of a university credit course, including but not limited to preparation and delivery of course content, development, administration and marking of assignments, tests and examinations, calculations and submission of grades, provide direction and supervision of TA's, and holding regular office hours.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than past teaching experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: In progress Ph.D. in relevant area of Earth Science
qualifications_preferred: Completed Ph.D. in relevant area of  Earth Science
salery: In accordance with the current CUPE3902 Unit 1 Collective Agreement, the Course Instructor rate of pay will be $9,276.01 excludes vacation pay for a half course.
ta_support: Dependent on enrollment / TA support provided for practical sections.
tutorial: For the most up-to-date course timetable and delivery methods, please visit UTM timetable planner: https://ttb.utoronto.ca/.

application_procedure:
Please submit an application on https://taships.iit.artsci.utoronto.ca/env/login.

Applications should include: i) a letter of application, explaining why you are qualified for the course(s) to which you are applying, and ii) a CV (including academic and applied environmental experience). 

Please note: The letter of application should be combined with your CV, and uploaded as a single file, where you are asked to upload your CV. Applicants are requested not to apply to TA positions for which they do not have the qualifications listed under "Minimum Qualifications".
duties: Duties include preparing for and leading tutorial sessions, grading assignments, tests and final assessments, responding to student email requests, and general assistance. Additional duties supported through the Writing Integrated Teaching program, which may include additional training, benchmarking sessions, and other activities.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: A University of Toronto graduate student who has demonstrated scholarly expertise in Environmental Studies: drawing from the sciences, social sciences and the humanities to explore major social, cultural, economic, regulatory, ethical, ecological and technological aspects of environmental issues.
qualifications_preferred: An interdisciplinary environmental background is an asset.

duties: Leading up to two tutorials each week, meeting with students one-on-one, grading assignments, and answering student queries through email. **Please note, the delivery method for this course is currently in person. In keeping with current circumstances, the course delivery method may change as determined by the Faculty or the College.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: University of Toronto graduate student who has completed one year of graduate study and who has a demonstrated scholarly expertise in English literature, Academic Writing, Professional Writing, and/or Rhetoric. qualifications_preferred: Some experience with teaching courses in or marking papers in professional writing and/or report writing would be an advantage. Experience teaching business/commerce/management students would be an advantage.
