application_procedure: Please submit a cover letter, CV, and the contact information for two references to typ.office@utoronto.ca by June 24, 2025  at 5 PM.
duties:
The Introduction to Indigenous Studies seminar is designed to support TYP
students enrolled in INS201H1F and INS202H1S to identify key information in lecture and provide a thorough
understanding of course material and assignments. The seminar will further explore ideas, methods
and themes of the discipline of Indigenous Studies. The development of the field of Indigenous
Studies in Canada will form an important focus in the first half. The second part of the course will
address “history and politics,” including an overview of the historical processes of diplomacy,
alliances, and treaty-making. The duties of this position include:                                                                                                  (a) Referencing INS201 and INS202 syllabi to instruct and help students learn while providing an
encouraging, creative, and positive environment for academic assistance for a variety of
learning needs.
(b) Preparation and presentation of course materials and assignments for seminars  to help
students succeed in academic writing for social science, history, and critical theory.
(c) Counsel students with respect to academic progress such as study-skills, academic reading,
organization, and time management and assist them in obtaining appropriate counseling for
non-academic matters. 
(d) Evaluate attendance and course participation for the course. 
(e) Attending scheduled faculty and staff meetings.
(f) Submitting marks for assessments associated with TYP053Y1.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Applicants must be  Graduate Students enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies of the University of Toronto or those who have made application to be enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies of the University of Toronto. Preference will be given to applicants engaged in research in Indigenous Studies. Applicants must have experience teaching INS201Y1 content and in-depth knowledge of Transitional YearProgramme (TYP) student supports, curriculum, and culture. Applicants must demonstrate a commitment to equity and anti-oppressive/social-justice approaches to education and familiarity with Quercus and online/remote instructional methods.
qualifications_preferred:
Applicants must have previous work experience, and/or coursework relating to anti-oppression
and/or social-justice approaches to post-secondary education, knowledge
of/experience with adult education and the University of Toronto, and  experience advising students and
providing academic support. In depth knowledge of the University
of Toronto community and University of Toronto student experience is an asset.

application_procedure:

Rebecca Bi

Asian Institute, Munk School of Global Affairs & Public Policy 
University of Toronto 
ai.asianstudies@utoronto.ca 
 
YOU MUST USE THE FOLLOWING FOR YOUR SUBJECT LINE: APPLICATION: COURSE CODE: LAST NAME. Please attach your C.V. and cover letter as PDFs, and label your attachments as follows: Last Name_First Name_Cover; Last Name_First Name_CV.
duties:
• Developing syllabus 
• Planning and teaching weekly lectures 
• Creating and marking tests and assignments 
• Providing scheduled office hours for academic counselling 
• Maintaining Quercus site 

Duties of this position shall be performed at the campus on which the position is located.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than past teaching experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Candidate must be a post-doctoral fellow in any of the following or related disciplines: History, Anthropology, Comparative Literature, Political Science, Sociology with current knowledge of research in the area as the course is an important component of the Contemporary Asian Studies program.
qualifications_preferred: The candidate would preferably have pedagogical and/or research experience that addresses larger global themes, such as Digital Development within Asia, Global Digital Cultures, Technology and Society, Design and Technology through deep site-specific study. A strong scholarly background in disciplines relevant to the course is preferred.

application_procedure: Follow application procedures outlined here: https://www.eas.utoronto.ca/about/job-postings/cupe-unit-1/
duties: As part of an English Language Learning (ELL) Initiative in Arts and Science, the Lead TA will work with the ELL Coordinator to support Course Instructors and train regular course TAs in selected courses. The ELL Lead TA will perform the following duties: Participate in training sessions with ELL faculty during the summer, as well as additional training sessions throughout the year; Meet in the summer with ELL Coordinator and ELL course instructors to plan course assignments and tutorials; Design and lead training sessions and consultations for course TAs (on topics such as responding to and grading assignments, planning tutorial related to scholarly reading, etc.) through Fall and Winter terms; Develop and/or adapt resources on language and writing instruction (such as marking rubrics and assignment guides) for course instructors, TAs, and students; Communicate regularly with ELL course instructors, ELL Coordinator, and others to coordinate activities; Collect data (e.g., surveys, student writing samples, etc.); Document activities (e.g., unit goals, monthly updates, write a final a report about the initiative’s impact in the unit, etc.)
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Current EAS PhD student with previous experience (at least two years' experience as a course TA in EAS's core courses (EAS103H1, EAS105H1, and/or EAS209H1), including leading tutorials); Excellent oral and interpersonal skills, particularly the ability to work effectively with and show tact when communicating with course instructors and TAs; Strong administrative skills, including scheduling meetings and planning, time management, meeting multiple deadlines, and documenting work; Able to prioritize tasks; Strong facilitation and presentation skills and/or experience leading workshops; Evidence of superior writing skills in their discipline; Flexible schedule, able to accommodate short notice requests for meetings
qualifications_preferred: Current EAS PhD student with previous experience (at least two years' experience as a course TA in EAS's core courses (EAS103H1, EAS105H1, and/or EAS209H1), including leading tutorials); Excellent oral and interpersonal skills, particularly the ability to work effectively with and show tact when communicating with course instructors and TAs; Strong administrative skills, including scheduling meetings and planning, time management, meeting multiple deadlines, and documenting work; Able to prioritize tasks; Strong facilitation and presentation skills and/or experience leading workshops; Evidence of superior writing skills in their discipline; Flexible schedule, able to accommodate short notice requests for meetings.

application_procedure: Please submit your teaching resume with cover letter as one (1) PDF to for each position you are interested in to ugta.ece@utoronto.ca.  Please label the PDF document using the following format: LastName, FirstName - CI - Course Code.  Messages in the body of the email will not be considered.  Please ONLY include your student number if you are a student. Otherwise UTORID/personnel if you are a Post-Doc. Deadline is June 30, 2025 at 11:59PM.
duties: Deliver lectures in accordance with class schedule and description; supervise TAs (if applicable); evaluate student's work and assign final grades.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Graduate students and post-doctoral fellows who possess and demonstrate expertise in the subject matter and have experience teaching (or serving as a teaching assistant in) in this or a similar course. The successful candidate must demonstrate a track record of professionalism and aptitude for instruction.
qualifications_preferred: Preference given to candidates with strong academic qualifications.  Ph.D. or post-doctoral fellows are preferred. Having repeated relevant experiences teaching (or having served as a teaching assistant) especially in this course offering is a strong asset.

duties: The design, preparation and delivery of course content, including teaching lectures or seminars; creation of courseware; the development and administration of assignments, tests and examinations; invigilation of the final examination; the marking and grading of student work, and the submission of grades to the CIRHR in accordance with established policies and procedures; the maintenance of reasonable hours of student contact outside scheduled classroom hours; and, if applicable,  the supervision of the day-to-day work of teaching assistants assigned to the course.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than past teaching experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: A PhD or a PhD with ABD status related to IRHR required.
qualifications_preferred: Research expertise in related areas.

application_procedure: Apply online at: https://forms.office.com/r/TZ58STUSmT  For general inquiries, feel free to contact course_instructor@cs.toronto.edu
duties:
“- Preparing and delivering the lectures in-person on campus as scheduled.
- Handling course administration including: maintaining the course website on quercus; developing marking schemes/syllabus; planning tutorial content (when applicable); developing course assessments including assignments, projects, quizzes, tests, and final assessments.
- Providing appropriate contact time outside of class to students, through office hours, email, the course website and/or the course bulletin board.
- Preparing the breakdown of hours for TA duties in the course and supervising the TAs.
- Ensuring that tutorials and/or labs are delivered appropriately by the TAs.
- Managing the grading for the course, which is largely done by the TAs, and carrying out any grading not handled by the TAs.
- Invigilating term tests and the final exam when applicable.
- Managing the grades, including the timely completion and release of grades and feedback to students throughout the term; submitting final course grades (due January 9, 2026).
- As there are other sections of the same course that term, coordinating with the other instructor(s) to maintain consistency (this includes using common assignments and a common final exam)
- where relevant, instructors must work together to coordinate automarking of assignments.

While there is a lot of room for creativity in course delivery, instructors will be expected to follow the basic content and style used by the faculty members who normally teach the course, and must get approval from these faculty members or the Associate Chair, Undergraduate on any substantial changes to the course content or assessment methods. Instructors will also be expected to consult with the department's Teaching Support group when creating the course syllabus, final exam, and test(s).
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
"- BSc in computer science or related field
- completed or working towards a graduate degree in computer science or a related field preferred
- demonstrated expertise in topic area of the course
- strong organizational, interpersonal, and communication skills
- previous experience as a course Instructor or Teaching Assistant, in the course (or its equivalent) is an asset
- demonstrated evidence of excellence in Teaching an asset
qualifications_preferred: N/A
ta_support: approx 60 hours of support per 30 students

duties: Duties: • Preparation As part of the Writing-Integrated Teaching (WIT) program, a writing instruction initiative in Arts and Science, the Lead Writing TA (LWTA) will work with the WIT staff and WIT Unit Contact to support course instructors and TAs in selected courses, as well as support undergraduate student writing development overall in the hiring department. The LWTA will perform the following duties: • Participate in training sessions (with LWTAs from other units) in July and throughout the year (late August, early January, and an end-of-year event): • Read book chapters, articles, etc. on writing pedagogy • Meet with WIT staff, departmental WIT Contacts, and course instructors to plan writing assignments activities and for tutorials, labs, or lectures • Design and lead training sessions and consultations for course TAs on writing-related topics, such as providing feedback to students on critical reading, writing, planning tutorial/lab activities related to writing, etc. • Develop and/or adapt resources on writing instruction (such as marking rubrics and assignments) for instructors, TAs, and students • Communicate regularly by email and in person with course instructors, WIT staff, departmental WIT Contacts and others to implement WIT activities • Collaborate with LWTAs in other units by meeting in peer groups and sharing writing instruction resources • Collect and analyze data on WIT (e.g., surveys, student writing samples, TA and instructor focus groups, etc.) • Document activities (e.g., help draft unit WIT goals, provide monthly updates, write a final a report about WIT activities in the unit, etc.)  and leading tutorials • Marking assignments, tests, final exam  NOTE: this position isn’t eligible for the subsequent appointment
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: • Current PhD student with least two years' experience as a course TA, whether leading tutorials/ labs, in-class instruction, or grading; education in translational medicine or biotechnology preferred; • Excellent oral communication and interpersonal skills, particularly the ability to work effectively with and show tact when communicating with administrators, course instructors, and TAs; • Strong administrative skills, including ability to schedule meetings and training sessions, plan and document work; • Strong time management skills with ability to meet multiple deadlines; • Strong facilitation and presentation skills and/or experience leading/facilitating workshops; • Evidence of superior writing skills in their discipline (writing samples are mandatory; writing samples must be individually authored and include science communication, e.g. scientific project report, and a reflective essay); • Flexible schedule, willing and able to accommodate short notice requests for meetings with WIT staff, course instructors, and TAs.
qualifications_preferred: N/A
salery: SGS I/II - $51.93 hour (Sept till Dec, 2024)/$52.97 (Jan till Apr, 2025) + vacation pay

application_procedure: https://taships.iit.artsci.utoronto.ca/ggr
duties:
As part of the Writing-Integrated Teaching (WIT) program, a writing-instruction initiative in Arts and Science, the Lead Writing TA (LWTA) will work with WIT staff and the WIT Unit Contact to support course instructors and TAs in selected courses, as well as support undergraduate student writing development overall in the hiring department. The LWTA will perform the following duties: • Participate in training sessions (with LWTAs from other units) in July and throughout the year (late August, early January, and an end-of-year event). 
Summer training will be held online on July 15, July 16, and July 17, 2025. 
Subsequent training sessions will be held in person on August 25, 2025, January 9, 2026, and March 30, 2026. All training sessions are held from 1:00 to 4:00 pm Eastern. 
•	Read book chapters, articles, etc. on writing education pedagogy 
•	Meet with WIT staff, departmental WIT Contacts, and course instructors to plan writing assignments activities and for tutorials, labs, or lectures 
•	Design and lead training sessions and consultations for course TAs on writing-related topics, such as providing feedback to students on critical reading, writing, planning tutorial/lab activities related to writing, etc. 
•	Develop and/or adapt resources on writing instruction (such as marking rubrics and assignments) for instructors, TAs, and students 
•	Communicate regularly by email and in person with course instructors, WIT staff, departmental WIT Contacts and others to implement WIT activities
•	Collaborate with LWTAs in other units by meeting in peer groups and sharing writing instruction resources 
•	Collect and analyze data on WIT (e.g., surveys, student writing samples, TA and instructor focus groups, etc.) 
• Document activities (e.g., help draft unit WIT goals, provide monthly updates, write a final a report about WIT activities in the unit, etc.)
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Current PhD student in Geography or Planning with at least two years’ experience as a course TA leading tutorials or labs or grading. To ensure that as many TAs as possible benefit from the rich professional development opportunity and experience gained from the WIT program, only students who have served as LWTA for less than 3 years may apply. 
• Excellent oral communication and interpersonal skills, particularly the ability to work effectively with and show tact when communicating with administrators, course instructors, and TAs 
• Strong administrative skills, including ability to schedule meetings and training sessions, plan and document work
• Strong time management skills with ability to meet multiple deadlines
• Strong facilitation and presentation skills and/or experience leading/facilitating workshops
• Evidence of superior writing skills in their discipline 
• Flexible schedule, willing and able to accommodate short notice requests for meetings with WIT staff, course instructors, and TAs

application_procedure:
Apply here: https://www.utsc.utoronto.ca/webapps/cupehiring/dept/ctl/app/ta

To complete the application, please upload the following documents:
1. Cover Letter
2. Curriculum Vitae or Resume
3. A short writing sample (maximum 4 pages)
4. Contact information of THREE references.
5. Teaching evaluations (optional)
duties:
Teaching assistants will prepare motivating and stimulating materials that engage students in dynamic and interactive learning during practicums, provide constructive feedback and encourage confidence-building participation that develops students’ competence in academic oral and written communication. The special focus on rapid expansion of core vocabulary and academic writing provides the foundation and practical experience for students to cope effectively with university-level academic texts and assignment expectations. Students will engage actively in collaborative peer learning through consistent engagement with cell group interactions, Peer Scholar interactions, assigned group work outside class as well as through online learning.

Responsible for leading one in-person practicum session per week on Wednesdays, 11am - 12pm and/or 12pm – 1 pm in a way that establishes a robust highly-interactive learning community in the physical class; conduct office hours; grade projects, assignments, oral presentations and reflective journals, mid-terms and final assessments; facilitate the discussion board to stimulate an active and genuine exchange of ideas and deepening of critical thinking skills; grade quality of participation in discussion board and Peer Scholar; responsible for conducting assessments in accordance with criteria specified and provide supportive written feedback and guidance that helps individual students to develop their vocabulary and increase their critical thinking and academic writing skills.

Appointment Dates: September 2, 2025 – December 23, 2025
Practicum Dates: September 10 – November 12, 2025
Practicum Times: Wednesdays, 11am- 12pm and/or 12:00-1:00pm (In-person)
Office Hours: To be arranged
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
A minimum Master’s degree in a relevant field; a minimum of 3 years of experience teaching at a university; evidence of ability to support the development of critical thinking and academic communication skills (especially academic writing) of multilingual university students who have significant needs related to English for Academic Purposes; relevant experience teaching writing one-on-one and/or teaching in university courses with a significant writing instruction component; demonstrated ability and high level of comfort discussing and teaching grammar to students in university courses; excellent communication and motivational skills, demonstrated ability to be perceived as highly approachable by students; and demonstrated ability to create a lively, highly motivating learning environment and sustain students’ interest in learning (as reflected through student attendance and engagement throughout the semester).

Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_preferred: Experience supporting student learning through an online environment; training in writing, education, or applied linguistics would be a great asset; experience working with a diverse group of students and training in second-language instruction at the university level; demonstrated evidence of active involvement in research in the field of second language writing; experience with teaching that involves critical Artificial Intelligence (AI) literacy with specified use of Generative AI in achieving course goals; a demonstrated ability and experience using Canvas (Quercus), and knowledge and experience using web conferencing tools such as Microsoft Teams and Zoom.
salery: January 1, 2025: UG/SGS I/SGS II/PDF: $52.97 per hour + 4% vacation pay

job_title: Various non-credit courses and GCAC Writing Centre
application_procedure: For detailed descriptions of GCAC offerings and for application instructions, visit: https://www.gcac.utoronto.ca/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/GCAC-Job-Board-Posting-CUPE-Unit-1-202506.pdf
duties: The GCAC’s mandate is to help graduate students improve their effectiveness in academic writing and speaking. We seek teachers whose qualifications and experience prepare them to teach graduate students effectively. Please view the link in Application Procedure for full details of duties.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Applicants must be registered graduate students or postdoctoral fellows at the University of Toronto. The GCAC non-credit courses listed below generally run for three to six weeks, two hours a week, and applicants will be considered either for individual course modules or for a combination of course modules, based on qualifications, experience, and availability.
qualifications_preferred: Preference will be given to applicants who have experience and/or training in teaching advanced speakers of multiple languages, experience with scientific writing, and/or experience teaching across multiple disciplines.

department: Centre for Industrial Relations & Human Resources
application_procedure: For detailed information on the application procedure go to https://www.cirhr.utoronto.ca/employment-opportunities/cirhr-job-postings.   Select the accordion named: "CUPE Unit 1 Opportunities - Course Instructor Positions - Undergraduate"  and follow the instructions listed there.
duties: The design, preparation and delivery of course content, including teaching lectures or seminars; creation of courseware; the development and administration of assignments, tests and examinations; invigilation of the final examination; the marking and grading of student work, and the submission of grades to the CIRHR in accordance with established policies and procedures; the maintenance of reasonable hours of student contact outside scheduled classroom hours; and, if applicable,  the supervision of the day-to-day work of teaching assistants assigned to the course.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: A PhD or a PhD with ABD status required.
qualifications_preferred: Teaching experience in this course preferred.
ta_support: approx. 240 TA hours, depending on course enrolment.
tutorial: This course is online asynchronous delivery, and will include a mandatory in-person final exam.

department: Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering
application_procedure: Please submit your teaching resume with cover letter as one (1) PDF to for each position you are interested in to ugta.ece@utoronto.ca.  Please label the PDF document using the following format: LastName, FirstName - CI - Course Code.  Messages in the body of the email will not be considered.  Please ONLY include your student number if you are a student. Otherwise UTORID/personnel if you are a Post-Doc. Deadline is June 24, 2025 at 11:59PM
duties: Deliver lectures in accordance with class schedule and description; supervise TAs (if applicable); evaluate student's work and assign final grades.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Graduate students and post-doctoral fellows who possess and demonstrate expertise in the subject matter and have experience teaching (or serving as a teaching assistant in) in this or a similar course. The successful candidate must demonstrate a track record of professionalism and aptitude for instruction.
qualifications_preferred: Preference given to candidates with strong academic qualifications.  Ph.D. or post-doctoral fellows are preferred. Having repeated relevant experiences teaching (or having served as a teaching assistant) especially in this course offering is a strong asset.

salery: $9,442.98 (excludes vacation pay) per half course. Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

application_procedure: Applicants must submit a cover letter, C.V. or resume, and a list of references by June 30, 2025. Applications should be sent via email to the Robert Gillespie Academic Skills Centre at academicskills.utm@utoronto.ca with the subject title: PELS Unit 1 Job Posting.
duties: As a Teaching Assistant for the Robert Gillespie Academic Skills Centre’s (RGASC) Professional English Language Skills (PELS), the TA will perform the following duties: Monitoring PELS discussion boards, Facilitating participation in student hours and events (in person), and Marking assessments using answer keys
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Applicants must be currently enrolled as a Master or PhD graduate student at the University of Toronto. Applicants should have at least two years of experience as a Teaching Assistant at the University of Toronto. Applicants should have experience and facility with administering Quercus sites. Applicants must have the ability to work effectively with and show tact when communicating with PELS administrators, students, and faculty.
qualifications_preferred: Preference will be given to a student who has completed PELS or is interested in helping students with academic English language learning and study skills development and has an interest in intercultural communication strategies and linguistic diversity. An academic background in writing and communication or experience in writing instruction (as a student learner or teaching assistant) is an asset but not required – training will be provided.

application_procedure:
Applicants should submit a brief cover letter (max. 1 page), C.V., a proposed course description (max. 1 page), and contact information for two academic references by June 20, 2025. Graduate students, please indicate the status of your dissertation in your cover letter, i.e. amount completed and estimated date of your thesis examination. 
 
Please submit applications to:
Professor Andrea Walkden, Associate Chair - Undergraduate Studies, Department of English
C/O Jessie Chen, Undergraduate Assistant
University of Toronto, Department of English
To Jessie Chen at tzuyu.chen@utoronto.ca
duties: All duties associated with teaching an undergraduate course, including preparing the course outline, syllabus and lectures, delivering lectures, developing, marking and administering course assignments, tests & exams, holding regular office hours and the supervision of any assigned TA support. ENG286H1 is co-taught with an instructor from Computer Science.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.

tutorial:
In Person: Tuesdays 11 am to 1 pm; 
TA support hours 490 hours (3x140, 1xadmin70) from English; 240 hours (4x60) from Computer Science

job_title: Invigilator, Services to Persons with a Disability
appointment_size: Hours of work are determined by the tests and examinations scheduled, therefore minimum/maximum hours cannot be guaranteed
application_procedure:
•  Complete application form before closing date (July 2nd at 11:59 PM). Applicants must be signed in to their UofT webmail account to access the form. 
• Application form link: https://forms.office.com/r/rucCu8nyMd. If you are experiencing technical difficulties with the form, email accessexams.utsc@utoronto.ca to report the issues you are having
Applicants submit:
•  Resume is required; cover letter is optional
•  Responses to two supplementary questions (posted on application form).
•  University of Toronto student number and confirmation of registration status on ACORN
•  Confirmation of availability for the period outlined above
•  NOTE: Incomplete applications will not be considered
duties:
Incumbents will supervise the writing of tests and examinations written by students with documented disabilities who are registered with AccessAbility Services at the University of Toronto, Scarborough (UTSC). 
Responsibilities include, but are not limited to, the following: 
•Supervising in-person tests and examinations written by persons wwith disability-related accommodations; some remote shifts may be required
• Through active invigilation, maintain the integrity of tests and exams by adhering to departmental, academic faculty, and university policies and procedures
• Maintaining confidentiality and security of student and test/exam information
• Ensuring the provision of disability-related accommodations to students as authorized by AccessAbility Services
• Monitoring test/exam time allotments
• Handling student concerns/problems and referring to Test and Exam Coordinator where appropriate
• Documenting and responding to anomalous situations
• Preparing completed in-person tests/exams for return delivery 
• Verifying student identification
• Maintaining required administrative records
• Ensuring the physical exam space, including supply cabinet, Invigilator work station, and students' writing areas, are kept clean and organized
qualifications:
• Applicants must be currently registered as students pursuing a degree at the University of Toronto  
• Applicants must demonstrate a commitment to the principles of equity and inclusion 
• Applicants must be available for in-person invigilation shifts
• Preference will be given to candidates who have experience working with persons with disabilities
• Experience invigilating tests/exams is an asset
• First Aid and CPR certification is an asset
• Completion of Mental Health First Aid and/or suicide prevention training is an asset
• Applicants are required to provide availability between the hours of 7:30 AM - 10:30 PM, Monday through Saturday
• A minimum of 10 hours of availability must be provided each week between Mondays - Fridays from 7:30 AM to 6 PM AND
• A minimum of 45 hours of availability must be provided during all final exam periods. N.B. Occasional Sunday shifts may also be required
Successful candidates must participate in mandatory training, which will consist of:
• September training sessions: more details to follow
• New Invigilators are required to participate in a minimum of 3 in-person shadow shifts prior to the examination period
• New Invigilators are required to participate in preliminary in-person independent shifts after completion of their shadow shifts
Please note that all aspects of training will be scheduled between 7:30 AM - 5:00 PM Monday through Saturday.
Successful candidates must attend three final exam meetings to be held the week before deferred and final exam period begins. The meetings will be scheduled between 8:30 AM – 5:00 PM, Mondays to Fridays.
• Ability to respond effectively to emergency, difficult or sensitive situations while maintaining appropriate boundaries
• Ability to demonstrate integrity and professionalism, while remaining calm under pressure
• Problem solving and resourcefulness
• Attention to details
• Situational awareness and the ability to manage changing priorities
• Understanding and ability to apply relevant University and government policies, procedures and legislation 
• Initiative
• Ability to collaborate with others and work in a team setting
• Organizational
• Communication (both oral and written)
• Strong computer skills, including MS Office; Experience with assistive technology and Zoom an asset
salery: $48.88/hr + $1/hr worked on Saturday and Sunday shifts + 4% vacation pay

job_title: WGSI Lead Writing Teaching Assistant LWTA
application_procedure: Applicants should apply online by the deadline at https://taships.iit.artsci.utoronto.ca/wgs/postings
duties:
As part of the Writing-Integrated Teaching (WIT) program, a writing-instruction initiative in Arts and Science, the Lead Writing TA (LWTA) will work with WIT staff and the WIT Unit Contact to support course instructors and TAs in selected courses, as well as support undergraduate student writing development overall in the hiring department.

The LWTA will perform the following duties:
• Participate in training sessions (with LWTAs from other units) in July and throughout the year (late August, early January, and an end-of-year event)
• Read book chapters, articles, etc. on writing education pedagogy
• Meet with WIT staff, departmental WIT Contacts, and course instructors to plan writing assignments activities and for tutorials, labs, or lectures
• Design and lead training sessions and consultations for course TAs on writing-related topics, such as providing feedback to students on critical reading, writing, planning tutorial/lab activities related to writing, etc.
• Develop and/or adapt resources on writing instruction (such as marking rubrics and assignments) for instructors, TAs, and students
• Communicate regularly by email and in person with course instructors, WIT staff, departmental WIT Contacts and others to implement WIT activities
• Collaborate with LWTAs in other units by meeting in peer groups and sharing writing instruction resources
• Collect and analyze data on WIT (e.g., surveys, student writing samples, TA and instructor focus groups, etc.)
• Document activities (e.g., help draft unit WIT goals, provide monthly updates, write a final a report about WIT activities in the unit, etc.)

NOTE: The applicant must be available for approximately 25 hours of training and preparatory work (e.g., consultations with WIT coordinators, contacts, and course instructors) throughout July and August. Mandatory training sessions will be held online on July 15, July 16, and July 17, 2025; subsequent mandatory training sessions will be held in person on August 25, 2025, January 9, 2026, and March 30, 2026. All training sessions are held from 1:00 to 4:00 pm Eastern.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: • Current PhD student with least two years’ experience as a course TA, whether leading tutorials/ labs, in-class instruction, or grading • Excellent oral communication and interpersonal skills, particularly the ability to work effectively with and show tact when communicating with administrators, course instructors, and TAs • Strong administrative skills, including ability to schedule meetings and training sessions, plan and document work • Strong time management skills with ability to meet multiple deadlines • Strong facilitation and presentation skills and/or experience leading/facilitating workshops • Evidence of superior writing skills in their discipline • Flexible schedule, willing and able to accommodate short notice requests for meetings with WIT staff, course instructors, and TAs
qualifications_preferred: An academic background in Women and Gender Studies at the graduate level is preferred.

qualifications_preferred: MA in Comparative Literature or a closely related discipline.  Demonstrated knowledge of critical and literary theory relevant to the course.  Scholarly expertise relevant to the course material (as shown, for example, by dissertation research).  At least two years of previous experience as a Teachng Assistant in position(s) involving tutorials or as a Course Instructor.  Evidence of effective teaching and communication skills.  Knowledge of some of the literature in the original language is a preferred qualification.    In this course we will explore the early stages of European colonialism and the long-term impact of the transformations it inaugurted.

application_procedure: Submit a letter of application, a brief Statement of Teaching Philosophy, and a current CV to Aphrodite Gardner, Centre for Comparative Literature aphrodite.gardner@utoronto.ca
duties: The TA will conduct two weekly tutuorial sections, hold regular office hours, meet periodically with the instructor, and mark student essays.  The TA will also keep a record of student progress, which will be used by the instructor to help determine final marks.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: At least two years of previous experience as a Teaching Assistant in position(s) involving tutorials or as a Course Instructor. Evidence of effective teaching and communication skills. Knowledge of some of the literature in the original language is a preferred qualification.
qualifications_preferred:
MA in Comparative Literature or a closely related discipline.  Demonstrated knowledge of critical and literary Theory relevant to the course.  Scholarly expertise relevant to the course material (as shown, for example, by dissertation research). The principal focus of this course is the complex engagement of literature and the arts with both colonial and neo-colonial encounters between, Europe, Africa and the Americas over the last five hundred years. Exploring world cultures through the prism of colonial encounters facilitates discussions about the genesis of contemporary politics of globalisation as well as the accompanying dynamics of exploitation and resistance. This approach will also help to elucidate the ways in which contact between different world zones have been pivotal in the development of new national and regional cultures. In the process we engage with a wide range of questions including environmental precarity, food security, cultural violence, religious alterity, revolutions, and the coming of age of new subjectivities.   The material to be discussed will be organized under four broad headings: The Columbian Exchange in Cinema and Art; Colonial Encounters and Latin American Politics of Identity; Fictions of Colonial Encounters in West Africa; Narratives of Colonial and Neo-Colonial Encounters in the Caribbean. 

Primary texts may include works by
Miguel de Cervantes, Juan Rulfo, Octaivo Paz, Carlos Fuentes, William Shakespeare, Joseph Conrad, Chinua Achebe, Chimamanda Ngozi Adiche, Ama Ata Aidoo, Derek Walcott, Earl Lovelace, Olive Senior, Jaime Manrique and Anthony Winkler.

application_procedure: Submit a letter of application, a brief Statement of Teaching Philosophy, and a current CV to Aphrodite Gardner, Centre for Comparative Literature aphrodite.gardner@utoronto.ca
duties: The TA will conduct two weekly tutuorial sections, hold regular office hours, meet periodically with the instructor, and mark student essays and quizzes.  The TA will also keep a record of student progress, which will be used by the instructor to help determine final marks.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: At least two years of previous experience as a Teaching Assistant in position(s) involving tutorials or as a Course Instructor. Evidence of effective teaching and communication skills. Knowledge of some of the literature in the original language is a preferred qualification.
qualifications_preferred: MA in Comparative Literature or a closely related discipline.  Demonstrated knowedge of the critical and litrary theory relevant to the course materials (as shown, for example, by dissertation research).  This course explores representation as a cultural and political problem.  Representation is both a means of depicting or constructing reality and a means of constituting individual and collective subjectivities.  We will consider literary and other modes of representation in their historical contexts.  Texts will span a broad historical range and may include: Homer’s The Odyssey, excerpts from the Bible and the Koran, Aristotle’s Poetics, Dante’s Inferno, portions of Auerbach’s Figura, Eliot's The Waste Land, Barthes's Mythologies, Mahasweta Devi's Imaginary Maps, and Foucault's The History of Sexuality, vol 1.

job_title: An Introduction to Statistical Reasoning and Data Science
application_procedure:
Application information is available at https://www.statistics.utoronto.ca/employment-opportunities/cupe-positions-unit-1. 
The deadline to submit your application is September 26, 2022. For more information, you may contact: Angela Niazmand, Undergraduate and TA Administrator, Department of Statistical Sciences, University of Toronto
700 University Ave- Rm 9160- 6, Ontario Power Building, Toronto, ON M5G 1Z5, www.statistics.utoronto.ca, E-mail: jobapps.statistics@utoronto.ca

If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact
jobapps.statistics@utoronto.ca
This job is posted in accordance with the CUPE 3
duties:
Duties are in person unless otherwise indicated. Duties will include any or all of the following: attending lectures, running 
tutorial sessions, facilitating and evaluating student engagement on on-line discussion boards, participating in training 
sessions, meeting with the instructors, holding office hours, grading student homework including written reports, and 
assisting with grading of tests and exams.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Senior undergraduate students (third and fourth year) with strong background in statistics and exemplary communication skills may also be considered.
qualifications_preferred: Graduate student with strong background in statistics, as well as excellent communication and writing skills, and the ability to interact well with undergraduate students.
